Text

[I]0-i HAD just finished [my]0-i studies at [Oxford]1-oxford , and was taking a brief holiday from work before assuming definitely the management of [the estate]104-the estate . [[My]0-i father]105-my father died when [I]0-i was yet [a child]106-a child ; [[my]0-i mother]107-my mother followed [him]105-my father within a year ; and [I]0-i was nearly as much alone in [the world]108-the world as [a man]109-a man might find [himself]109-a man . [I]0-i had made little acquaintance with the history of [[my]0-i ancestors]110-my ancestors . Almost the only thing [I]0-i knew concerning [them]110-my ancestors was , that a notable number of [them]110-my ancestors had been given to study . [I]0-i had [myself]0-i so far inherited the tendency as to devote a good deal of [my]0-i time , though , [I]0-i confess , after a somewhat desultory fashion , to the physical sciences . It was chiefly the wonder [they]111-they woke that drew [me]0-i . [I]0-i was constantly seeing , and on the outlook to see , strange analogies , not only between the facts of different sciences of the same order , or between physical and metaphysical facts , but between physical hypotheses and suggestions glimmering out of the metaphysical dreams into which [I]0-i was in the habit of falling . [I]0-i was at the same time much given to a premature indulgence of the impulse to turn hypothesis into theory . Of [my]0-i mental peculiarities there is no occasion to say more . [The house]112-the house as well as [the family]113-the family was of some antiquity , but no description of it is necessary to the understanding of [my]0-i narrative . [It]112-the house contained [a fine library]114-a fine library , whose growth began before the invention of printing , and had continued to [my]0-i own time , greatly influenced , of course , by changes of taste and pursuit . Nothing surely can more impress upon [a man]109-a man the transitory nature of possession than [his]109-a man succeeding to [an ancient property]116-an ancient property ! Like a moving panorama mine has passed from before many eyes , and is now slowly flitting from before [my]0-i own . [The library]117-the library , although duly considered in many alterations of [the house]112-the house and additions to [it]117-the library , had nevertheless , like an encroaching state , absorbed [one room]119-one room after another until [it]117-the library occupied the greater part of the ground floor . [[Its]117-the library chief room]120-its chief room was large , and the walls of [it]117-the library were covered with books almost to the ceiling ; [the rooms into which [it]117-the library overflowed]121-the rooms into which it overflowed were of various sizes and shapes , and communicated in modes as various — by doors , by open arches , by short passages , by steps up and steps down . In [the great room]122-the great room [I]0-i mainly spent [my]0-i time , reading books of science , old as well as new ; for the history of the human mind in relation to supposed knowledge was what most of all interested [me]0-i . [Ptolemy]18-ptolemy , [Dante]19-dante , [the two Bacons]123-the two bacons , and [Boyle]20-boyle were even more to [me]0-i than [Darwin]21-darwin or [Maxwell]22-maxwell , as so much nearer [the vanished van]124-the vanished van breaking into the dark of ignorance . In the evening of a gloomy day of August [I]0-i was sitting in [my]0-i usual place , [my]0-i back to one of the windows , reading . It had rained the greater part of the morning and afternoon , but just as the sun was setting , the clouds parted in front of [him]125-him , and [he]125-him shone into [the room]126-the room . [I]0-i rose and looked out of the window . In the centre of [the great lawn]127-the great lawn the feathering top of the fountain column was filled with [his]125-him red glory . [I]0-i turned to resume [my]0-i seat , when [my]0-i eye was caught by the same glory on the one picture in [the room]126-the room — a portrait , in a sort of niche or little shrine sunk for it in the expanse of book - filled shelves . [I]0-i knew it as the likeness of [one of [[my]0-i ancestors]110-my ancestors]129-one of my ancestors , but had never even wondered why it hung there alone , and not in [the gallery]131-the gallery , or one of [the great rooms]132-the great rooms , among the other family portraits . The direct sunlight brought out the painting wonderfully ; for the first time [I]0-i seemed to see it , and for the first time it seemed to respond to [my]0-i look . With [my]0-i eyes full of the light reflected from it , something , [I]0-i can not tell what , made [me]0-i turn and cast a glance to the farther end of [the room]126-the room , when [I]0-i saw , or seemed to see , a tall figure reaching up a hand to a bookshelf . The next instant , [my]0-i vision apparently rectified by the comparative dusk , [I]0-i saw [no one]134-no one , and concluded that [my]0-i optic nerves had been momentarily affected from within . [I]0-i resumed [my]0-i reading , and would doubtless have forgotten the vague , evanescent impression , had it not been that , having occasion a moment after to consult a certain volume , [I]0-i found but a gap in the row where it ought to have stood , and the same instant remembered that just there [I]0-i had seen , or fancied [I]0-i saw , [the old man in search of a book]135-the old man in search of a book . [I]0-i looked all about the spot but in vain . The next morning , however , there it was , just where [I]0-i had thought to find it ! [I]0-i knew of [no one in [the house]112-the house]136-no one in the house likely to be interested in such a book . Three days after , another and yet odder thing took place . In one of the walls was the low , narrow door of [a closet]138-a closet , containing some of the oldest and rarest of the books . It was a very thick door , with a projecting frame , and it had been the fancy of [some ancestor to cross it with shallow shelves , filled with book - backs only]139-some ancestor to cross it with shallow shelves , filled with book - backs only . The harmless trick may be excused by the fact that the titles on the sham backs were either humorously original , or those of books lost beyond hope of recovery . [I]0-i had a great liking for the masked door . To complete the illusion of it , [some inventive workman]140-some inventive workman apparently had shoved in , on the top of one of the rows , a part of a volume thin enough to lie between it and the bottom of the next shelf : [he]140-some inventive workman had cut away diagonally a considerable portion , and fixed the remnant with one of its open corners projecting beyond the book - backs . The binding of the mutilated volume was limp vellum , and one could open the corner far enough to see that it was manuscript upon parchment . Happening , as [I]0-i sat reading , to raise [my]0-i eyes from the page , [my]0-i glance fell upon this door , and at once [I]0-i saw that the book described , if book it may be called , was gone . Angrier than any worth [I]0-i knew in it justified , [I]0-i rang the bell , and [the butler]141-the butler appeared . When [I]0-i asked [him]141-the butler if [he]141-the butler knew what had befallen it , [he]141-the butler turned pale , and assured [me]0-i [he]141-the butler did not . [I]0-i could less easily doubt [his]141-the butler word than [my]0-i own eyes , for [he]141-the butler had been all [his]141-the butler life in [the family]113-the family , and [a more faithful servant]143-a more faithful servant never lived . [He]141-the butler left on [me]0-i the impression , nevertheless , that [he]141-the butler could have said something more . In the afternoon [I]0-i was again reading in [the library]117-the library , and coming to a point which demanded reflection , [I]0-i lowered the book and let [my]0-i eyes go wandering . The same moment [I]0-i saw the back of [a slender old man]145-a slender old man , in a long , dark coat , shiny as from much wear , in the act of disappearing through the masked door into [the closet beyond]146-the closet beyond . [I]0-i darted across [the room]126-the room , found the door shut , pulled it open , looked into [the closet]148-the closet , which had no other issue , and , seeing [nobody]149-nobody , concluded , not without uneasiness , that [I]0-i had had a recurrence of [my]0-i former illusion , and sat down again to [my]0-i reading . Naturally , however , [I]0-i could not help feeling a little nervous , and presently glancing up to assure [myself]0-i that [I]0-i was indeed alone , started again to [my]0-i feet , and ran to the masked door — for there was the mutilated volume in its place ! [I]0-i laid hold of it and pulled : it was firmly fixed as usual ! [I]0-i was now utterly bewildered . [I]0-i rang the bell ; [the butler]141-the butler came ; [I]0-i told [him]141-the butler all [I]0-i had seen , and [he]141-the butler told [me]0-i all [he]141-the butler knew . [He]141-the butler had hoped , [he]141-the butler said , that [the old gentleman]151-the old gentleman was going to be forgotten ; it was well [no one]134-no one but [myself]0-i had seen [him]151-the old gentleman . [He]141-the butler had heard a good deal about [him]151-the old gentleman when first [he]141-the butler served in [the house]112-the house , but by degrees [he]151-the old gentleman had ceased to be mentioned , and [he]141-the butler had been very careful not to allude to [him]151-the old gentleman . " [The place]2672-the place was haunted by [an old gentleman]2673-an old gentleman , was it ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said . [He]141-the butler answered that at one time [everybody]154-everybody believed it , but the fact that [I]0-i had never heard of it seemed to imply that the thing had come to an end and was forgotten . [I]0-i questioned [him]141-the butler as to what [he]141-the butler had seen of [the old gentleman]151-the old gentleman . [He]141-the butler had never seen [him]151-the old gentleman , [he]141-the butler said , although [he]141-the butler had been in [the house]112-the house from the day [[my]0-i father]105-my father was eight years old . [[My]0-i grandfather]158-my grandfather would never hear a word on the matter , declaring that [whoever alluded to it]159-whoever alluded to it should be dismissed without a moment 's warning : it was nothing but a pretext of [the maids]160-the maids , [he]141-the butler said , for running into the arms of [the men]161-the men ! but [old Sir Ralph]23-old sir ralph believed in nothing [he]141-the butler could not see or lay hold of . Not [one of [the maids]160-the maids]162-one of the maids ever said [she]162-one of the maids had seen the apparition , but [a footman]164-a footman had left [the place]2672-the place because of it . [An ancient woman in [the village]167-the village]166-an ancient woman in the village had told [him]141-the butler a legend concerning [a Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , long time librarian to " that Sir Upward whose portrait hangs there among the books . "[166-an ancient woman in the village] [Sir Upward]25-sir upward was [a great reader]168-a great reader , [she]166-an ancient woman in the village said — not of such books only as were wholesome for [men]169-men to read , but of strange , forbidden , and evil books ; and in so doing , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , who was probably the devil [himself]24-mr. raven , encouraged [him]25-sir upward . Suddenly [they]170-they both disappeared , and [Sir Upward]25-sir upward was never after seen or heard of , but [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven continued to show [himself]24-mr. raven at uncertain intervals in [the library]117-the library . There were some who believed [he]24-mr. raven was not dead ; but both [he]24-mr. raven and [the old woman]172-the old woman held it easier to believe that [a dead man]173-a dead man might revisit [the world]108-the world [he]24-mr. raven had left , than [that one who went on living for hundreds of years]175-that one who went on living for hundreds of years should be [a man at all]176-a man at all . [He]24-mr. raven had never heard that [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven meddled with anything in [the house]112-the house , but [he]24-mr. raven might perhaps consider [himself]24-mr. raven privileged in regard to the books . How [the old woman]172-the old woman had learned so much about [him]24-mr. raven [he]24-mr. raven could not tell ; but the description [she]172-the old woman gave of [him]24-mr. raven corresponded exactly with the figure [I]0-i had just seen . " [I]24-mr. raven hope it was but a friendly call on the part of [the old gentleman]151-the old gentleman ! "[24-mr. raven] [he]24-mr. raven concluded , with a troubled smile . [I]0-i told [him]24-mr. raven [I]0-i had no objection to any number of visits from [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , but it would be well [he]24-mr. raven should keep to [his]24-mr. raven resolution of saying nothing about [him]24-mr. raven to [the servants]179-the servants . Then [I]0-i asked [him]24-mr. raven if [he]24-mr. raven had ever seen the mutilated volume out of its place ; [he]24-mr. raven answered that [he]24-mr. raven never had , and had always thought it a fixture . With that [he]24-mr. raven went to it , and gave it a pull : it seemed immovable . NOTHING more happened for some days . [I]0-i think it was about a week after , when what [I]0-i have now to tell took place . [I]0-i had often thought of the manuscript fragment , and repeatedly tried to discover some way of releasing it , but in vain : [I]0-i could not find what held it fast . But [I]0-i had for some time intended a thorough overhauling of the books in the closet , its atmosphere causing [me]0-i uneasiness as to their condition . One day the intention suddenly became a resolve , and [I]0-i was in the act of rising from [my]0-i chair to make a beginning , when [I]0-i saw [the old librarian]180-the old librarian moving from the door of [the closet]148-the closet toward the farther end of [the room]126-the room . [I]0-i ought rather to say only that [I]0-i caught sight of something shadowy from which [I]0-i received the impression of [a slight , stooping man]183-a slight , stooping man , in a shabby dress - coat reaching almost to [his]24-mr. raven heels , the tails of which , disparting a little as [he]24-mr. raven walked , revealed thin legs in black stockings , and large feet in wide , slipper - like shoes . At once [I]0-i followed [him]24-mr. raven : [I]0-i might be following a shadow , but [I]0-i never doubted [I]0-i was following something . [He]24-mr. raven went out of [the library]117-the library into [the hall]185-the hall , and across to the foot of the great staircase , then up the stairs to [the first floor]186-the first floor , where lay [the chief rooms]187-the chief rooms . Past [these rooms]188-these rooms , [I]0-i following close , [he]24-mr. raven continued [his]24-mr. raven way , through [a wide corridor]189-a wide corridor , to the foot of a narrower stair leading to [the second floor]190-the second floor . Up that [he]24-mr. raven went also , and when [I]0-i reached the top , strange as it may seem , [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in [a region almost unknown to [me]0-i]191-a region almost unknown to me . [I]0-i never had [brother]192-brother or [sister]193-sister to incite to such romps as make [children familiar with nook and cranny]194-children familiar with nook and cranny ; [I]0-i was [a mere child]195-a mere child when [[my]0-i guardian]196-my guardian took [me]0-i away ; and [I]0-i had never seen [the house]112-the house again until , about a month before , [I]0-i returned to take possession . Through passage after [passage]198-passage [we]199-we came to a door at the bottom of a winding wooden stair , which [we]199-we ascended . Every step creaked under [my]0-i foot , but [I]0-i heard no sound from that of [[my]0-i guide]200-my guide . Somewhere in the middle of [the stair]201-the stair [I]0-i lost sight of [him]200-my guide , and from the top of [it]201-the stair the shadowy shape was nowhere visible . [I]0-i could not even imagine [I]0-i saw [him]200-my guide . [The place]2672-the place was full of shadows , but [he]200-my guide was not one of them . [I]0-i was in [the main garret]203-the main garret , with huge beams and rafters over [my]0-i head , great spaces around [me]0-i , a door here and there in sight , and long vistas whose gloom was thinned by a few lurking cobwebbed windows and small dusky skylights . [I]0-i gazed with a strange mingling of awe and pleasure : the wide expanse of garret was [my]0-i own , and unexplored ! In the middle of [it]203-the main garret stood an unpainted inclosure of rough planks , the door of which was ajar . Thinking [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven might be [there]204-there , [I]0-i pushed the door , and entered . [The small chamber]205-the small chamber was full of light , but such as dwells in [places deserted]206-places deserted : [it]205-the small chamber had a dull , disconsolate look , as if [it]205-the small chamber found itself of no use , and regretted having come . [A few rather dim sunrays , marking their track through the cloud of motes that had just been stirred up]207-a few rather dim sunrays , marking their track through the cloud of motes that had just been stirred up , fell upon a tall mirror with a dusty face , old - fashioned and rather narrow — in appearance an ordinary glass . It had an ebony frame , on the top of which stood a black eagle , with outstretched wings , in [his]200-my guide beak a golden chain , from whose end hung a black ball . [I]0-i had been looking at rather than into the mirror , when suddenly [I]0-i became aware that it reflected neither [the chamber]208-the chamber nor [[my]0-i own person]209-my own person . [I]0-i have an impression of having seen the wall melt away , but what followed is enough to account for any uncertainty:—could [I]0-i have mistaken for a mirror the glass that protected a wonderful picture ? [I]0-i saw before [me]0-i [a wild country]210-a wild country , broken and heathy . Desolate hills of no great height , but somehow of strange appearance , occupied the middle distance ; along the horizon stretched [the tops of [a far - off mountain range]212-a far - off mountain range]211-the tops of a far - off mountain range ; nearest [me]0-i lay [a tract of moorland]213-a tract of moorland , flat and melancholy . Being short - sighted , [I]0-i stepped closer to examine the texture of a stone in the immediate foreground , and in the act espied , hopping toward [me]0-i with solemnity , a large and ancient raven , whose purply black was here and there softened with gray . [He]200-my guide seemed looking for worms as [he]200-my guide came . Nowise astonished at the appearance of a live creature in a picture , [I]0-i took another step forward to see [him]200-my guide better , stumbled over something — doubtless the frame of the mirror — and stood nose to beak with the bird : [I]0-i was in the open air , on [a houseless heath]214-a houseless heath ! [I]0-i TURNED and looked behind [me]0-i : all was vague and uncertain , as when one can not distinguish between fog and field , between cloud and [mountain - side]215-mountain - side . One fact only was plain — that [I]0-i saw nothing [I]0-i knew . Imagining [myself]0-i involved in a visual illusion , and that touch would correct sight , [I]0-i stretched [my]0-i arms and felt about [me]0-i , walking in this direction and that , if haply , where [I]0-i could see nothing , [I]0-i might yet come in contact with something ; but [my]0-i search was vain . Instinctively then , as to the only living thing near [me]0-i , [I]0-i turned to the raven , which stood a little way off , regarding [me]0-i with an expression at once respectful and quizzical . Then the absurdity of seeking counsel from [such a one]216-such a one struck [me]0-i , and [I]0-i turned again , overwhelmed with bewilderment , not unmingled with fear . Had [I]0-i wandered into a region where both the material and psychical relations of [[our]217-our world]218-our world had ceased to hold ? Might [a man]109-a man at any moment step beyond the realm of order , and become the sport of [the lawless]220-the lawless ? Yet [I]0-i saw the raven , felt the ground under [my]0-i feet , and heard a sound as of wind in [the lowly plants around [me]0-i]221-the lowly plants around me ! " How did [I]0-i get [here]2675-here ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said — apparently aloud , for the question was immediately answered . " [You]0-i came through the door , "[0-i] replied an odd , rather harsh voice . [I]0-i looked behind , then all about [me]0-i , but saw no human shape . The terror that madness might be at hand laid hold upon [me]0-i : must [I]0-i henceforth place no confidence either in [my]0-i senses or [my]0-i consciousness ? The same instant [I]0-i knew it was the raven that had spoken , for [he]222-he stood looking up at [me]0-i with an air of waiting . The sun was not shining , yet the bird seemed to cast a shadow , and the shadow seemed part of [himself]222-he . [I]0-i beg [[my]0-i reader]223-my reader to aid [me]0-i in the endeavour to make [myself]0-i intelligible — if here understanding be indeed possible between [us]224-us . [I]0-i was in [a world]225-a world , or call it a state of things , an economy of conditions , an idea of existence , so little correspondent with the ways and modes of [this world]226-this world — which [we]224-us are apt to think [the only world]227-the only world , that the best choice [I]0-i can make of word or phrase is but an adumbration of what [I]0-i would convey . [I]0-i begin indeed to fear that [I]0-i have undertaken an impossibility , undertaken to tell what [I]0-i can not tell because no speech at [my]0-i command will fit the forms in [my]0-i mind . Already [I]0-i have set down statements [I]0-i would gladly change did [I]0-i know how to substitute a truer utterance ; but as often as [I]0-i try to fit the reality with nearer words , [I]0-i find [myself]0-i in danger of losing the things [themselves]228-themselves , and feel like [one in process of awaking from a dream]229-one in process of awaking from a dream , with the thing that seemed familiar gradually yet swiftly changing through a succession of forms until its very nature is no longer recognisable . [I]0-i bethought [me]0-i that a bird capable of addressing [a man]109-a man must have the right of [a man to a civil answer]231-a man to a civil answer ; perhaps , as a bird , even a greater claim . A tendency to croak caused a certain roughness in [his]232-i speech , but [his]232-i voice was not disagreeable , and what [he]232-i said , although conveying little enlightenment , did not sound rude . " [I]0-i did not come through any door , "[0-i] [I]0-i rejoined . " [I]233-the raven saw [you]0-i come through it!—saw [you]0-i with [my]233-the raven own ancient eyes ! "[233-the raven] asserted [the raven]233-the raven , positively but not disrespectfully . " [I]0-i never saw any door ! "[0-i] [I]0-i persisted . " Of course not ! "[232-i] [he]232-i returned ; " all the doors [you]0-i had yet seen — and [you]0-i have n't seen many — were doors in ; here [you]0-i came upon a door out ! The strange thing to [you]0-i , "[232-i] [he]232-i went on thoughtfully , " will be , that the more doors [you]0-i go out of , the farther [you]0-i get in ! "[232-i] " Oblige [me]233-the raven by telling [me]233-the raven where [I]233-the raven am . "[233-the raven] " That is impossible . [You]0-i know nothing about whereness . The only way to come to know where [you]0-i are is to begin to make [yourself]0-i at [home]2676-home . "[232-i] " How am [I]232-i to begin that where everything is so strange ? "[232-i] " By doing something . "[233-the raven] " What ? "[232-i] " Anything ; and the sooner [you]0-i begin the better ! for until [you]0-i are at [home]2676-home , [you]0-i will find it as difficult to get out as it is to get in . "[232-i] " [I]232-i have , unfortunately , found it too easy to get in ; once out [I]232-i shall not try again ! "[232-i] " [You]0-i have stumbled in , and may , possibly , stumble out again . Whether [you]0-i have got in unfortunately remains to be seen . "[233-the raven] " Do [you]232-i never go out , [sir]2678-sir ? "[232-i] " When [I]232-i please [I]232-i do , but not often , or for long . [[Your]0-i world]2679-your world is such a half - baked sort of place , it is at once so childish and so self - satisfied — in fact , it is not sufficiently developed for an old raven — at [your]0-i service ! "[232-i] " Am [I]232-i wrong , then , in presuming that [a man]109-a man is superior to a bird ? "[232-i] " That is as it may be . [We]2681-we do not waste [our]2681-we intellects in generalising , but take [man]2682-man or bird as [we]2681-we find [him.—I]2681-we think it is now [my]233-the raven turn to ask [you]0-i a question ! "[233-the raven] " [You]234-you have the best of rights , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied , " in the fact that [you]234-you can do so ! "[0-i] " Well answered ! "[234-you] [he]234-you rejoined . " Tell [me]234-you , then , who [you]0-i are — if [you]0-i happen to know . "[234-you] " How should [I]233-the raven help knowing ? [I]233-the raven am [myself]233-the raven , and must know ! "[233-the raven] " If [you]0-i know [you]0-i are [yourself]0-i , [you]0-i know that [you]0-i are not [somebody else]2683-somebody else ; but do [you]0-i know that [you]0-i are [yourself]0-i ? Are [you]0-i sure [you]0-i are not [[your]0-i own]2684-your own father?—or , excuse [me]0-i , [your]0-i own fool?—Who are [you]0-i , pray ? "[0-i] [I]0-i became at once aware that [I]0-i could give [him]235-him no notion of who [I]0-i was . Indeed , who was [I]0-i ? It would be no answer to say [I]0-i was who ! Then [I]0-i understood that [I]0-i did not know [myself]0-i , did not know what [I]0-i was , had no grounds on which to determine that [I]0-i was one and not another . As for the name [I]0-i went by in [[my]0-i own world]236-my own world , [I]0-i had forgotten it , and did not care to recall it , for it meant nothing , and what it might be was plainly of no consequence here . [I]0-i had indeed almost forgotten that there it was a custom for [everybody]154-everybody to have a name ! So [I]0-i held [my]0-i peace , and it was [my]0-i wisdom ; for what should [I]0-i say to a creature such as [this raven , who saw through accident into entity]238-this raven , who saw through accident into entity ? " Look at [me]239-he , "[239-he] [he]239-he said , " and tell [me]239-he who [I]239-he am . "[239-he] As [he]239-he spoke , [he]239-he turned [his]239-he back , and instantly [I]0-i knew [him]239-he . [He]239-he was no longer a raven , but [a man above the middle height with a stoop , very thin , and wearing a long black tail - coat]240-a man above the middle height with a stoop , very thin , and wearing a long black tail - coat . Again [he]239-he turned , and [I]0-i saw [him]239-he [a raven]241-a raven . " [I]0-i have seen [you]239-he before , [sir]2678-sir , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , feeling foolish rather than surprised . " How can [you]0-i say so from seeing [me]239-he behind ? "[239-he] [he]239-he rejoined . " Did [you]0-i ever see [yourself]0-i behind ? [You]0-i have never seen [yourself]0-i at all!—Tell [me]239-he now , then , who [I]239-he am . "[239-he] " [I]0-i humbly beg [your]239-he pardon , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered : " [I]0-i believe [you]239-he were once [the librarian of [[our]2687-our house]2688-our house]2686-the librarian of our house , but more who [I]0-i do not know . "[0-i] " Why do [you]239-he beg [my]239-he pardon ? "[239-he] " Because [I]0-i took [you]239-he for a raven , "[0-i] [I]0-i said — seeing [him]242-him before [me]0-i as plainly a raven as bird or [man]2682-man could look . " [You]0-i did [me]242-him no wrong , "[242-him] [he]242-him returned . " Calling [me]244-me [a raven]241-a raven , or thinking [me]244-me one , [you]0-i allowed [me]244-me existence , which is the sum of what [one]2690-one can demand of [his]2690-one fellow - beings . Therefore , in return , [I]244-me will give [you]0-i a lesson:—No [one]2690-one can say [he]2690-one is [himself]2690-one , until first [he]2690-one knows that [he]2690-one is , and then what [himself]2690-one is . In fact , [nobody]149-nobody is [himself]2690-one , and [himself]2690-one is [nobody]149-nobody . There is more in it than [you]0-i can see now , but not more than [you]0-i need to see . [You]0-i have , [I]244-me fear , got into [this region]2694-this region too soon , but none the less [you]0-i must get to be at [home]2676-home in [it]2694-this region ; for [home]2676-home , as [you]0-i may or may not know , is the only place where [you]0-i can go out and in . There are places [you]0-i can go into , and places [you]0-i can go out of ; but the one place , if [you]0-i do but find it , where [you]0-i may go out and in both , is [home]2676-home . "[244-me] [He]244-me turned to walk away , and again [I]0-i saw [the librarian]245-the librarian . [He]244-me did not appear to have changed , only to have taken up [his]244-me shadow . [I]0-i know this seems nonsense , but [I]0-i can not help it . [I]0-i gazed after [him]244-me until [I]0-i saw [him]244-me no more ; but whether distance hid [him]244-me , or [he]244-me disappeared among the heather , [I]0-i can not tell . Could it be that [I]0-i was dead , [I]0-i thought , and did not know it ? Was [I]0-i in what [we]246-we used to call [the world beyond the grave]247-the world beyond the grave ? and must [I]0-i wander about seeking [my]0-i place in it ? How was [I]0-i to find [myself]0-i at [home]2676-home ? The raven said [I]0-i must do something : what could [I]0-i do here?—And would that make [me]0-i [somebody]249-somebody ? for now , alas , [I]0-i was [nobody]149-nobody ! [I]0-i took the way [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven had gone , and went slowly after [him]24-mr. raven . Presently [I]0-i saw a wood of tall slender pine - trees , and turned toward it . The odour of it met [me]0-i on [my]0-i way , and [I]0-i made haste to bury [myself]0-i in it . Plunged at length in its twilight glooms , [I]0-i spied before [me]0-i something with a shine , standing between two of the stems . It had no colour , but was like the translucent trembling of the hot air that rises , in a radiant summer noon , from the sun - baked ground , vibrant like the smitten chords of a musical instrument . What it was grew no plainer as [I]0-i went nearer , and when [I]0-i came close up , [I]0-i ceased to see it , only the form and colour of the trees beyond seemed strangely uncertain . [I]0-i would have passed between the stems , but received a slight shock , stumbled , and fell . When [I]0-i rose , [I]0-i saw before [me]0-i the wooden wall of [the garret chamber]251-the garret chamber . [I]0-i turned , and there was the mirror , on whose top the black eagle seemed but that moment to have perched . Terror seized [me]0-i , and [I]0-i fled . Outside [the chamber]208-the chamber [the wide garret spaces]253-the wide garret spaces had an uncanny look . [They]253-the wide garret spaces seemed to have long been waiting for something ; it had come , and [they]253-the wide garret spaces were waiting again ! A shudder went through [me]0-i on the winding stair : [the house]112-the house had grown strange to [me]0-i ! something was about to leap upon [me]0-i from behind ! [I]0-i darted down the spiral , struck against the wall and fell , rose and ran . On [the next floor]255-the next floor [I]0-i lost [my]0-i way , and had gone through several passages a second time ere [I]0-i found the head of the stair . At the top of [the great stair]256-the great stair [I]0-i had come to [myself]0-i a little , and in a few moments [I]0-i sat recovering [my]0-i breath in [the library]117-the library . Nothing should ever again make [me]0-i go up that last terrible stair ! The garret at [the top of [it]256-the great stair]258-the top of it pervaded [the whole house]259-the whole house ! It sat upon [it]256-the great stair , threatening to crush [me]0-i out of [it]256-the great stair ! [The brooding brain of [the building]261-the building]260-the brooding brain of the building , [it]256-the great stair was full of [mysterious dwellers]262-mysterious dwellers , one or other of whom might any moment appear in [the library where [I]0-i sat]263-the library where i sat ! [I]0-i was nowhere safe ! [I]0-i would let , [I]0-i would sell the dreadful place , in which an aërial portal stood ever open to [creatures whose life was other than human]264-creatures whose life was other than human ! [I]0-i would purchase a crag in [Switzerland]2-switzerland , and thereon build [a wooden nest of one story with never a garret]265-a wooden nest of one story with never a garret above [it]265-a wooden nest of one story with never a garret , guarded by some grand old peak that would send down nothing worse than a few tons of whelming rock ! [I]0-i knew all the time that [my]0-i thinking was foolish , and was even aware of a certain undertone of contemptuous humour in it ; but suddenly it was checked , and [I]0-i seemed again to hear the croak of the raven . " If [I]0-i know nothing of [my]0-i own garret , "[0-i] [I]0-i thought , " what is there to secure [me]0-i against [my]0-i own brain ? Can [I]0-i tell what it is even now generating?—what thought it may present [me]0-i the next moment , the next month , or a year away ? What is at the heart of [my]0-i brain ? What is behind [my]0-i think ? Am [I]0-i there at all?—Who , what am [I]0-i ? "[0-i] [I]0-i could no more answer the question now than when the raven put it to [me]0-i in — at—"Where in?—where at ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said , and gave [myself]0-i up as knowing anything of [myself]0-i or [the universe]266-the universe . [I]0-i started to [my]0-i feet , hurried across [the room]126-the room to the masked door , where the mutilated volume , sticking out from the flat of soulless , bodiless , non - existent books , appeared to beckon [me]0-i , went down on [my]0-i knees , and opened it as far as its position would permit , but could see nothing . [I]0-i got up again , lighted a taper , and peeping as into a pair of reluctant jaws , perceived that the manuscript was verse . Further [I]0-i could not carry discovery . Beginnings of lines were visible on the left - hand page , and ends of lines on the other ; but [I]0-i could not , of course , get at the beginning and end of a single line , and was unable , in what [I]0-i could read , to make any guess at the sense . The mere words , however , woke in [me]0-i feelings which to describe was , from their strangeness , impossible . Some dreams , some poems , some musical phrases , some pictures , wake feelings such as one never had before , new in colour and form — spiritual sensations , as it were , hitherto unproved : here , some of the phrases , some of the senseless half - lines , some even of the individual words affected [me]0-i in similar fashion — as with the aroma of an idea , rousing in [me]0-i a great longing to know what the poem or poems might , even yet in their mutilation , hold or suggest . [I]0-i copied out a few of the larger shreds attainable , and tried hard to complete some of the lines , but without the least success . The only thing [I]0-i gained in the effort was so much weariness that , when [I]0-i went to bed , [I]0-i fell asleep at once and slept soundly . In the morning all that horror of the empty garret spaces had left [me]0-i . THE sun was very bright , but [I]0-i doubted if the day would long be fine , and looked into the milky sapphire [I]0-i wore , to see whether the star in it was clear . It was even less defined than [I]0-i had expected . [I]0-i rose from the breakfast - table , and went to the window to glance at the stone again . There had been heavy rain in the night , and on [the lawn]268-the lawn was a thrush breaking [his]269-he way into the shell of a snail . As [I]0-i was turning [my]0-i ring about to catch the response of the star to the sun , [I]0-i spied a keen black eye gazing at [me]0-i out of the milky misty blue . The sight startled [me]0-i so that [I]0-i dropped the ring , and when [I]0-i picked it up the eye was gone from it . The same moment the sun was obscured ; a dark vapour covered [him]269-he , and in a minute or two the whole sky was clouded . The air had grown sultry , and a gust of wind came suddenly . A moment more and there was a flash of lightning , with a single sharp thunder - clap . Then the rain fell in torrents . [I]0-i had opened the window , and stood there looking out at the precipitous rain , when [I]0-i descried a raven walking toward [me]0-i over the grass , with solemn gait , and utter disregard of the falling deluge . Suspecting who [he]269-he was , [I]0-i congratulated [myself]0-i that [I]0-i was safe on the ground - floor . At the same time [I]0-i had a conviction that , if [I]0-i were not careful , something would happen . [He]269-he came nearer and nearer , made a profound bow , and with a sudden winged leap stood on the window - sill . Then [he]269-he stepped over the ledge , jumped down into [the room]126-the room , and walked to the door . [I]0-i thought [he]269-he was on [his]269-he way to [the library]117-the library , and followed [him]269-he , determined , if [he]269-he went up [the stair]201-the stair , not to take one step after [him]269-he . [He]269-he turned , however , neither toward [the library]117-the library nor [the stair]201-the stair , but to a little door that gave upon a grass - patch in [a nook between two portions of [the rambling old house]276-the rambling old house]275-a nook between two portions of the rambling old house . [I]0-i made haste to open [it]277-it for [him]269-he . [He]269-he stepped out into [[its]277-it creeper - covered porch]278-its creeper - covered porch , and stood looking at the rain , which fell like a huge thin cataract ; [I]0-i stood in the door behind [him]269-he . The second flash came , and was followed by a lengthened roll of more distant thunder . [He]269-he turned [his]269-he head over [his]269-he shoulder and looked at [me]0-i , as much as to say , " [You]0-i hear that ? "[269-he] then swivelled it round again , and anew contemplated the weather , apparently with approbation . So human were [his]269-he pose and carriage and the way [he]269-he kept turning [his]269-he head , that [I]0-i remarked almost involuntarily , " Fine weather for the worms , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven ! "[0-i] " Yes , "[269-he] [he]269-he answered , in the rather croaky voice [I]0-i had learned to know , " the ground will be nice for [them]2698-them to get out and in!—It must be a grand time on [the steppes of Uranus]2699-the steppes of uranus ! "[269-he] [he]269-he added , with a glance upward ; " [I]269-he believe it is raining there too ; it was , all the last week ! "[269-he] " Why should that make it a grand time ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . " Because the animals there are all burrowers , "[269-he] [he]269-he answered , " — like the field - mice and the moles here.—They will be , for ages to come . "[269-he] " How do [you]269-he know that , if [I]0-i may be so bold ? "[0-i] [I]0-i rejoined . " As [any one]2700-any one would who had been there to see , "[269-he] [he]269-he replied . " It is a great sight , until [you]2701-you get used to it , when [the earth]2702-the earth gives a heave , and out comes a beast . [You]2701-you might think it a hairy elephant or a deinotherium — but none of the animals are the same as [we]2703-we have ever had [here]2675-here . [I]269-he was almost frightened [myself]269-he the first time [I]269-he saw the dry - bog - serpent come wallowing out — such a head and mane ! and such eyes!—But the shower is nearly over . It will stop directly after the next thunder - clap . There it is ! "[269-he] A flash came with the words , and in about half a minute the thunder . Then the rain ceased . " Now [we]2703-we should be going ! "[233-the raven] said [the raven]233-the raven , and stepped to the front of [the porch]280-the porch . " Going where ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . " Going where [we]2703-we have to go , "[269-he] [he]269-he answered . " [You]269-he did not surely think [you]269-he had got [home]2676-home ? " That does not make any difference — at least not much , "[269-he] [he]269-he answered . " This is the way ! "[0-i] " [I]269-he am quite content where [I]269-he am . "[269-he] " [You]269-he think so , but [you]269-he are not . Come along . "[269-he] [He]269-he hopped from [the porch]280-the porch onto the grass , and turned , waiting . " [I]0-i will not leave [the house]112-the house to - day , "[0-i] [I]0-i said with obstinacy . " [You]269-he will come into [the garden]2708-the garden ! "[233-the raven] rejoined [the raven]233-the raven . " [I]0-i give in so far , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied , and stepped from [the porch]280-the porch . The sun broke through the clouds , and the rain - drops flashed and sparkled on the grass . [The raven]233-the raven was walking over it . " [You]269-he will wet [your]269-he feet ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried . " And mire [my]269-he beak , "[269-he] [he]269-he answered , immediately plunging it deep in the sod , and drawing out a great wriggling red worm . [He]269-he threw back [his]269-he head , and tossed it in the air . It spread great wings , gorgeous in red and black , and soared aloft . " Tut ! tut ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed ; " [you]269-he mistake , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven : worms are not the larvæ of butterflies ! "[0-i] " Never mind , "[269-he] [he]269-he croaked ; " it will do for once ! [I]269-he 'm not [a reading man]2709-a reading man at present , but sexton at the — at [a certain graveyard — cemetery]2710-a certain graveyard — cemetery , more properly — in — at — no matter where ! "[269-he] " [I]0-i see ! [you]269-he ca n't keep [your]269-he spade still : and when [you]269-he have nothing to bury , [you]269-he must dig something up ! Only [you]269-he should mind what it is before [you]269-he make it fly ! [No creature]2711-no creature should be allowed to forget what and where it came from ! "[0-i] " Why ? "[233-the raven] said [the raven]233-the raven . " Because it will grow proud , and cease to recognise [its]2711-no creature superiors . "[233-the raven] [No man]286-no man knows it when [he]286-no man is making [an idiot]287-an idiot of [himself]286-no man . " Where do the worms come from ? "[233-the raven] said [the raven]233-the raven , as if suddenly grown curious to know . " Why , from [the earth]2702-the earth , as [you]233-the raven have just seen ! "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " Yes , last ! "[233-the raven] [he]233-the raven replied . " But [they]2713-they ca n't have come from it first — for that will never go back to it ! "[233-the raven] [he]233-the raven added , looking up . [I]0-i looked up also , but could see nothing save a little dark cloud , the edges of which were red , as if with the light of the sunset . " Surely the sun is not going down ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed , struck with amazement . " Oh , no ! "[233-the raven] returned [the raven]233-the raven . " That red belongs to the worm . "[233-the raven] " [You]233-the raven see what comes of making [creatures]2714-creatures forget [their]2714-creatures origin ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried with some warmth . " It is well , surely , if it be to rise higher and grow larger ! "[233-the raven] [he]233-the raven returned . " But indeed [I]233-the raven only teach [them]2714-creatures to find it ! "[233-the raven] " Would [you]233-the raven have the air full of worms ? "[233-the raven] " That is the business of [a sexton]2715-a sexton . If only [the rest of the clergy]2716-the rest of the clergy understood it as well ! "[26-in] [In]26-in went [his]233-the raven beak again through the soft turf , and out came the wriggling worm . [He]233-the raven tossed it in the air , and away it flew . [I]0-i looked behind [me]0-i , and gave a cry of dismay : [I]0-i had but that moment declared [I]0-i would not leave [the house]112-the house , and already [I]0-i was [a stranger in [the strange land]292-the strange land]291-a stranger in the strange land ! " What right have [you]233-the raven to treat [me]0-i so , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said with deep offence . " Am [I]0-i , or am [I]0-i not , [a free agent]2717-a free agent ? "[0-i] " [A man]109-a man is as free as [he]109-a man chooses to make [himself]109-a man , never [an atom freer]2719-an atom freer , "[233-the raven] answered [the raven]233-the raven . "[233-the raven] " When [you]24-mr. raven have a will , [you]24-mr. raven will find that [no one]134-no one can . " If [you]24-mr. raven were [an individual]2721-an individual [I]0-i could not , therefore now [I]0-i do not . [You]24-mr. raven are but beginning to become [an individual]2721-an individual . "[0-i] All about [me]0-i was [a pine - forest]294-a pine - forest , in which [my]0-i eyes were already searching deep , in the hope of discovering an unaccountable glimmer , and so finding [my]0-i way [home]2676-home . But , alas ! how could [I]0-i any longer call [that house]296-that house [home]2676-home , where every door , every window opened into Out , and even [the garden]2708-the garden [I]0-i could not keep inside ! [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i looked discomfited . " Perhaps it may comfort [you]0-i , "[233-the raven] said [the raven]233-the raven , " to be told that [you]0-i have not yet left [[your]0-i house]2723-your house , neither has [[your]0-i house]2723-your house left [you]0-i . "[0-i] " In [the region of [the seven dimensions]2726-the seven dimensions]2725-the region of the seven dimensions , "[233-the raven] [he]233-the raven answered , with a curious noise in [his]233-the raven throat , and a flutter of [his]233-the raven tail . " [You]0-i had better follow [me]233-the raven carefully now for a moment , lest [you]0-i should hurt [some one]2727-some one ! "[233-the raven] " There is [nobody]149-nobody to hurt but [yourself]0-i , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven ! [I]0-i confess [I]0-i should rather like to hurt [you]0-i ! "[0-i] " That [you]0-i see [nobody]149-nobody is where the danger lies . But [you]0-i see that large tree to [your]0-i left , about thirty yards away ? "[0-i] " Of course [I]0-i do : why should [I]0-i not ? "[0-i] [I]0-i answered testily . " Ten minutes ago [you]0-i did not see it , and now [you]0-i do not know where it stands ! "[0-i] " [I]0-i do . "[233-the raven] " A prayer is a thought , a thing spiritual ! "[0-i] [I]0-i pursued . " Very true ! But if [you]0-i understood [any world besides [your]0-i own]2782-any world besides your own , [you]0-i would understand [your]0-i own much better.—When a heart is really alive , then it is able to think live things . There is [one heart all whose thoughts are strong , happy creatures]2783-one heart all whose thoughts are strong , happy creatures , and whose very dreams are lives . When [some]2784-some pray , [they]2784-some lift heavy thoughts from the ground , only to drop them on it again ; [others]2785-others send up [their]2785-others prayers in living shapes , this or that , the nearest likeness to each . All live things were thoughts to begin with , and are fit therefore to be used by [those that think]2786-those that think . [I]0-i had left spring and summer , autumn and sunshine behind [me]0-i , and come to the winter that waited for [me]0-i ! [I]0-i had set out in the prime of [my]0-i youth , and here [I]0-i was already!—But [I]0-i mistook . The day might well be long in [that region]338-that region , for it contained the seasons . [Winter]30-winter slept there , the night through , in [his]30-winter winding - sheet of ice ; with childlike smile , [Spring]31-spring came awake in the dawn ; at noon , [Summer]32-summer blazed abroad in [her]32-summer gorgeous beauty ; with the slow - changing afternoon , old Autumn crept in , and died at the first breath of the vaporous , ghosty night . As [we]339-we drew near [the cottage]340-the cottage , the clouded sun was rushing down [the steepest slope of the west]341-the steepest slope of the west , and [he]30-winter sank while [we]339-we were yet a few yards from the door . The same instant [I]0-i was assailed by a cold that seemed almost a material presence , and [I]0-i struggled across the threshold as if from the clutches of an icy death . A wind swelled up on [the moor]342-the moor , and rushed at the door as with difficulty [I]0-i closed it behind [me]0-i . Then all was still , and [I]0-i looked about [me]0-i . A candle burned on a deal table in the middle of [the room]126-the room , and the first thing [I]0-i saw was the lid of a coffin , as [I]0-i thought , set up against the wall ; but it opened , for it was a door , and [a woman]344-a woman entered . [She]344-a woman was all in white — as white as new - fallen snow ; and [her]344-a woman face was as white as [her]344-a woman dress , but not like snow , for at once it suggested warmth . [I]0-i thought [her]344-a woman features were perfect , but [her]344-a woman eyes made [me]0-i forget them . The life of [her]344-a woman face and [[her]344-a woman whole person]345-her whole person was gathered and concentrated in [her]344-a woman eyes , where it became light . It might have been coming death that made [her]344-a woman face luminous , but the eyes had life in them for a nation — large , and dark with a darkness ever deepening as [I]0-i gazed . A whole night - heaven lay condensed in each pupil ; all the stars were in its blackness , and flashed ; while round it for a horizon lay coiled an iris of the eternal twilight . What any eye is , [God]33-god only knows : [her]344-a woman eyes must have been coming direct out of [his]33-god own ! the still face might be a primeval perfection ; the live eyes were a continuous creation .
