" Upon occasion , "[357-the sexton] said [the sexton]357-the sexton at length , " it is more convenient to put [one]2690-one 's bird - self in front . [Every one]2818-every one , as [you]245-the librarian ought to know , has [a beast - self — and a bird - self]2819-a beast - self — and a bird - self , and [a stupid fish - self , ay , and a creeping serpent - self]2820-a stupid fish - self , ay , and a creeping serpent - self too — which it takes a deal of crushing to kill ! In truth [he]2818-every one has also a tree - self and a crystal - self , and [I]355-he do n't know how many selves more — all to get into harmony . [You]245-the librarian can tell what sort [a man]109-a man is by [his]109-a man creature that comes oftenest to the front . "[355-he] [He]355-he turned to [[his]355-he wife]358-his wife , and [I]0-i considered [him]355-he more closely . [He]355-he was above the ordinary height , and stood more erect than when last [I]0-i saw [him]355-he . [His]355-he face was , like [[his]355-he wife]358-his wife 's , very pale ; its nose handsomely encased the beak that had retired within it ; its lips were very thin , and even they had no colour , but [their]360-their curves were beautiful , and about them quivered a shadowy smile that had humour in it as well as love and pity . " [We]2822-we are in want of something to eat and drink , [wife]2800-wife , "[355-he] [he]355-he said ; " [we]2822-we have come a long way ! "[355-he] " [You]355-he know , [husband]2824-husband , "[358-his wife] [she]358-his wife answered , " [we]2822-we can give only to [him]355-he that asks . "[358-his wife] [She]358-his wife turned [her]358-his wife unchanging face and radiant eyes upon [mine]0-i . " Please give [me]0-i something to eat , [Mrs. Raven]35-mrs. raven , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " and something — what [you]358-his wife will — to quench [my]0-i thirst . "[0-i] " [Your]0-i thirst must be greater before [you]0-i can have what will quench it , "[358-his wife] [she]358-his wife replied ; " but what [I]358-his wife can give [you]0-i , [I]358-his wife will gladly . "[358-his wife] [She]358-his wife went to a cupboard in the wall , brought from it bread and wine , and set them on the table . [We]361-we sat down to the perfect meal ; and as [I]0-i ate , the bread and wine seemed to go deeper than the hunger and thirst . Anxiety and discomfort vanished ; expectation took their place . [I]0-i grew very sleepy , and now first felt weary . " [I]0-i have earned neither food nor sleep , [Mrs. Raven]35-mrs. raven , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " but [you]358-his wife have given [me]0-i the one freely , and now [I]0-i hope [you]358-his wife will give [me]0-i the other , for [I]0-i sorely need it . "[0-i] " Sleep is too fine a thing ever to be earned , "[357-the sexton] said [the sexton]357-the sexton ; " it must be given and accepted , for it is a necessity . But it would be perilous to use [this house]2825-this house as [a half - way hostelry]2826-a half - way hostelry — for the repose of a night , that is , merely . "[357-the sexton] A wild - looking little black cat jumped on [his]357-the sexton knee as [he]357-the sexton spoke . [He]357-the sexton patted it as one pats [a child]106-a child to make [it]106-a child go to sleep : [he]357-the sexton seemed to [me]0-i patting down the sod upon a grave — patting it lovingly , with an inward lullaby . " Here is one of [Mara]36-mara 's kittens ! "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton said to [[his]357-the sexton wife]358-his wife : " will [you]348-the woman give it something and put it out ? [she]348-the woman may want it ! "[357-the sexton] [The woman]348-the woman took it from [him]357-the sexton gently , gave it a little piece of bread , and went out with it , closing the door behind [her]348-the woman . " How then am [I]0-i to make use of [your]357-the sexton hospitality ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . " By accepting it to the full , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton answered . " [I]357-the sexton do not understand . "[357-the sexton] " In [this house]2825-this house [no one]134-no one wakes of [himself]134-no one . "[348-the woman] " Why ? "[357-the sexton] " Because [no one anywhere]2829-no one anywhere ever wakes of [himself]134-no one . [You]0-i can wake [yourself]0-i no more than [you]0-i can make [yourself]0-i . "[357-the sexton] " Then perhaps [you]357-the sexton or [Mrs. Raven]35-mrs. raven would kindly call [me]0-i ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said , still nowise understanding , but feeling afresh that vague foreboding . " [We]2830-we can not . "[0-i] " How dare [I]0-i then go to sleep ? "[0-i] [I]0-i cried . " If [you]357-the sexton would have the rest of [this house]2825-this house , [you]357-the sexton must not trouble [yourself]357-the sexton about waking . [You]357-the sexton must go to sleep heartily , altogether and outright . "[0-i] [My]0-i soul sank within [me]0-i . [The sexton]357-the sexton sat looking [me]0-i in the face . [His]357-the sexton eyes seemed to say , " Will [you]0-i not trust [me]357-the sexton ? "[357-the sexton] [I]0-i returned [his]357-the sexton gaze , and answered , " [I]0-i will . "[0-i] " Then come , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton said ; " [I]357-the sexton will show [you]0-i [[your]0-i couch]2832-your couch . "[357-the sexton] As [we]367-we rose , [the woman]348-the woman came in . [She]348-the woman took up the candle , turned to the inner door , and led the way . [I]0-i went close behind [her]348-the woman , and [the sexton]357-the sexton followed . THE air as of [an ice - house]370-an ice - house met [me]0-i crossing the threshold . The door fell - to behind [us]367-we . [The sexton]357-the sexton said something to [[his]357-the sexton wife]358-his wife that made [her]348-the woman turn toward us.—What a change had passed upon [her]348-the woman ! It was as if the splendour of [her]348-the woman eyes had grown too much for them to hold , and , sinking into [her]348-the woman countenance , made it flash with a loveliness like that of [Beatrice]37-beatrice in the white rose of the redeemed . Life itself , life eternal , immortal , streamed from it , an unbroken lightning . Even [her]348-the woman hands shone with a white radiance , every " pearl - shell helmet "[348-the woman] gleaming like a moonstone . [Her]348-the woman beauty was overpowering ; [I]0-i was glad when [she]348-the woman turned it from [me]0-i . But the light of the candle reached such a little way , that at first [I]0-i could see nothing of [the place]2672-the place . Presently , however , it fell on something that glimmered , a little raised from the floor . Was it a bed ? Could live thing sleep in such a mortal cold ? Then surely it was no wonder it should not wake of [itself]374-itself ! Beyond that appeared a fainter shine ; and then [I]0-i thought [I]0-i descried uncertain gleams on every side . A few paces brought [us]367-we to the first ; it was [a human form under a sheet , straight and still]375-a human form under a sheet , straight and still — whether of [man]2682-man or [woman]377-woman [I]0-i could not tell , for the light seemed to avoid the face as [we]367-we passed . [I]0-i soon perceived that [we]367-we were walking along an aisle of couches , on almost every one of which , with its head to [the passage]378-the passage , lay [something asleep or dead , covered with a sheet white as snow]379-something asleep or dead , covered with a sheet white as snow . [My]0-i soul grew silent with dread . Through aisle after [aisle]380-aisle [we]367-we went , among couches innumerable . [I]0-i could see only a few of them at once , but they were on all sides , vanishing , as it seemed , in the infinite.—Was it here lay [my]0-i choice of a bed ? Must [I]0-i go to sleep among the unwaking , with [no one]134-no one to rouse [me]0-i ? Was this [[the sexton]357-the sexton 's library]383-the sexton 's library ? were these [his]357-the sexton books ? Truly it was [no half - way house]384-no half - way house , [this chamber of the dead]385-this chamber of the dead ! " [One of [the cellars]2834-the cellars]2833-one of the cellars [I]24-mr. raven am placed to watch ! "[24-mr. raven] remarked [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven — in a low voice , as if fearing to disturb [[his]24-mr. raven silent guests]386-his silent guests . " Much wine is set here to ripen!—But it is dark for [a stranger]2835-a stranger ! "[24-mr. raven] [he]24-mr. raven added . " The moon is rising ; [she]358-his wife will soon be [here]2675-here , "[358-his wife] said [[his]24-mr. raven wife]358-his wife , and [her]358-his wife clear voice , low and sweet , sounded of ancient sorrow long bidden adieu . Even as [she]358-his wife spoke the moon looked in at an opening in the wall , and a thousand gleams of white responded to [her]358-his wife shine . But not yet could [I]0-i descry beginning or end of the couches . [They]388-they stretched away and away , as if for [all the disparted world]389-all the disparted world to sleep upon . For along [the far receding narrow ways]390-the far receding narrow ways , every couch stood by itself , and on each slept a lonely sleeper . [I]0-i thought at first [their]388-they sleep was death , but [I]0-i soon saw it was something deeper still — a something [I]0-i did not know . The moon rose higher , and shone through other openings , but [I]0-i could never see enough of [the place]2672-the place at once to know its shape or character ; now [it]2672-the place would resemble [a long cathedral nave]392-a long cathedral nave , now [a huge barn made into [a dwelling of tombs]394-a dwelling of tombs]393-a huge barn made into a dwelling of tombs . [She]358-his wife looked colder than any moon in the frostiest night of [the world]108-the world , and where [she]358-his wife shone direct upon them , cast a bluish , icy gleam on the white sheets and the pallid countenances — but it might be the faces that made the moon so cold ! Of such as [I]0-i could see , all were alike in the brotherhood of death , all unlike in the character and history recorded upon [them]388-they . Here lay [a man who had died]396-a man who had died — for although this was not death , [I]0-i have no other name to give it — in the prime of manly strength ; [his]396-a man who had died dark beard seemed to flow like a liberated stream from the glacier of [his]396-a man who had died frozen countenance ; [his]396-a man who had died forehead was smooth as polished marble ; a shadow of pain lingered about [his]396-a man who had died lips , but only a shadow . On the next couch lay the form of [a girl , passing lovely to behold]397-a girl , passing lovely to behold . The sadness left on [her]397-a girl , passing lovely to behold face by parting was not yet absorbed in perfect peace , but absolute submission possessed the placid features , which bore no sign of wasting disease , of " killing care or grief of heart : "[402-the most beautiful of all] if pain had been there , it was long charmed asleep , never again to wake . Many were [the beautiful that there lay very still]398-the beautiful that there lay very still — [some of [them]398-the beautiful that there lay very still [mere children]400-mere children]399-some of them mere children ; but [I]0-i did not see [one infant]401-one infant . [The most beautiful of all]402-the most beautiful of all was [a lady whose white hair , and that alone]403-a lady whose white hair , and that alone , suggested [her]403-a lady whose white hair , and that alone old when first [she]403-a lady whose white hair , and that alone fell asleep . On [her]403-a lady whose white hair , and that alone stately countenance rested — not submission , but a right noble acquiescence , an assurance , firm as the foundations of [the universe]266-the universe , that all was as it should be . On some faces lingered the almost obliterated scars of strife , the marrings of hopeless loss , the fading shadows of sorrows that had seemed inconsolable : the aurora of the great morning had not yet quite melted them away ; but those faces were few , and [every one that bore such brand of pain]405-every one that bore such brand of pain seemed to plead , " Pardon [me]405-every one that bore such brand of pain : [I]405-every one that bore such brand of pain died only yesterday ! "[405-every one that bore such brand of pain] or , " Pardon [me]405-every one that bore such brand of pain : [I]405-every one that bore such brand of pain died but a century ago ! "[405-every one that bore such brand of pain] That [some]2784-some had been dead for ages [I]0-i knew , not merely by [their]2784-some unutterable repose , but by something for which [I]0-i have neither word nor symbol . [We]407-we came at last to three empty couches , immediately beyond which lay the form of [a beautiful woman]408-a beautiful woman , a little past the prime of life . One of [her]408-a beautiful woman arms was outside the sheet , and [her]408-a beautiful woman hand lay with the palm upward , in its centre a dark spot . Next to [her]408-a beautiful woman was the stalwart figure of [a man of middle age]409-a man of middle age . [His]409-a man of middle age arm too was outside the sheet , the strong hand almost closed , as if clenched on the grip of a sword . [I]0-i thought [he]409-a man of middle age must be [a king who had died fighting for the truth]410-a king who had died fighting for the truth . " Will [you]0-i hold the candle nearer , [wife]2800-wife ? "[357-the sexton] whispered [the sexton]357-the sexton , bending down to examine [the woman]348-the woman 's hand . " It heals well , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton murmured to [himself]357-the sexton ; " the nail found in [her]408-a beautiful woman nothing to hurt ! "[357-the sexton] At last [I]0-i ventured to speak . " Are [they]2838-they not dead ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked softly . " [I]357-the sexton can not answer [you]0-i , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton replied in a subdued voice . " [I]357-the sexton almost forget what [they]2838-they mean by dead in [the old world]2839-the old world . If [I]357-the sexton said [a person]2840-a person was dead , [[my]357-the sexton wife]2760-my wife would understand one thing , and [you]0-i would imagine another.—This is but one of [[my]357-the sexton treasure vaults]2842-my treasure vaults , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton went on , " and all [[my]357-the sexton guests]2843-my guests are not laid in [vaults]2844-vaults : out there on [the moor]342-the moor [they]2843-my guests lie thick as the leaves of [a forest]2846-a forest after the first blast of [your]0-i winter — thick , let [me]357-the sexton say rather , as if the great white rose of heaven had shed its petals over it . All night the moon reads [their]2843-my guests faces , and smiles . "[357-the sexton] " But why leave [them]2843-my guests in the corrupting moonlight ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . " [Our]2847-our moon , "[357-the sexton] [he]357-the sexton answered , " is not like [yours]0-i — the old cinder of [a burnt - out world]2848-a burnt - out world ; [her]2760-my wife beams embalm the dead , not corrupt them . [You]0-i observe that here [the sexton]357-the sexton lays [his]357-the sexton dead on [the earth]2702-the earth ; be buries very few under it ! In [[your]0-i world]2679-your world [he]357-the sexton lays huge stones on them , as if to keep them down ; [I]357-the sexton watch for the hour to ring the resurrection - bell , and wake those that are still asleep . [[Your]0-i sexton]2852-your sexton looks at the clock to know when to ring the dead - alive to [church]332-church ; [I]357-the sexton hearken for the cock on the spire to crow ; ` Awake , [thou]2854-thou that sleepest , and arise from the dead ! ' "[357-the sexton] [I]0-i began to conclude that [the self - styled sexton]413-the self - styled sexton was in truth [an insane parson]414-an insane parson : the whole thing was too mad ! But how was [I]0-i to get away from it ? [I]0-i was helpless ! In this world of the dead , the raven and [[his]413-the self - styled sexton wife]358-his wife were the only living [I]0-i had yet seen : whither should [I]0-i turn for help ? [I]0-i was lost in [a space larger than imagination]416-a space larger than imagination ; for if here two things , or any parts of them , could occupy [the same space]417-the same space , why not twenty or ten thousand?—But [I]0-i dared not think further in that direction . " [You]0-i seem in [your]0-i dead to see differences beyond [my]0-i perception ! "[0-i] [I]0-i ventured to remark . " None of those [you]0-i see , "[413-the self - styled sexton] [he]413-the self - styled sexton answered , " are in truth quite dead yet , and some have but just begun to come alive and die . [Others]2785-others had begun to die , that is to come alive , long before [they]2785-others came to [us]2856-us ; and when such are indeed dead , that instant [they]2785-others will wake and leave [us]2856-us . Almost every night some rise and go . But [I]413-the self - styled sexton will not say more , for [I]413-the self - styled sexton find [my]413-the self - styled sexton words only mislead you!—This is the couch that has been waiting for [you]0-i , "[413-the self - styled sexton] [he]413-the self - styled sexton ended , pointing to one of the three . " Why just this ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said , beginning to tremble , and anxious by [parley]418-parley to delay . " For reasons which one day [you]0-i will be glad to know , "[413-the self - styled sexton] [he]413-the self - styled sexton answered . " Why not know [them]2857-they now ? "[413-the self - styled sexton] " That also [you]0-i will know when [you]0-i wake . "[413-the self - styled sexton] " But these are all dead , and [I]0-i am alive ! "[0-i] [I]0-i objected , shuddering . " Not much , "[357-the sexton] rejoined [the sexton]357-the sexton with a smile , " — not nearly enough ! Blessed be the true life that the pauses between its throbs are not death ! "[357-the sexton] " [The place]2672-the place is too cold to let [one]2690-one sleep ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " Do these find it so ? "[413-the self - styled sexton] [he]413-the self - styled sexton returned . " [They]2857-they sleep well — or will soon . Of cold [they]2857-they feel not a breath : it heals [their]2857-they wounds.—Do not be [a coward]2860-a coward , [Mr. Vane]27-mr. vane . Turn [your]0-i back on fear , and [your]0-i face to whatever may come . Give [yourself]0-i up to the night , and [you]0-i will rest indeed . Harm will not come to [you]0-i , but a good [you]0-i can not foreknow . "[357-the sexton] [The sexton]357-the sexton and [I]0-i stood by the side of the couch , [[his]357-the sexton wife]358-his wife , with the candle in [her]358-his wife hand , at the foot of it . [Her]358-his wife eyes were full of light , but [her]358-his wife face was again of a still whiteness ; it was no longer radiant . " Would [they]2857-they have [me]0-i make of [a charnel - house [my]0-i bed - chamber]2861-a charnel - house my bed - chamber ? "[0-i] [I]0-i cried aloud . " [I]0-i will not . [I]0-i will lie abroad on [the heath]326-the heath ; it can not be colder there ! "[0-i] " [I]0-i have just told [you]0-i that [the dead]2863-the dead are there also , said [the librarian]245-the librarian . "[0-i] [I]0-i will not , " [I]0-i cried again ; and in the compassing dark , the two gleamed out like spectres that waited on the dead ; [neither]2865-neither answered [me]0-i ; [each]2774-each stood still and sad , and looked at [the other]2867-the other . "[0-i] Be of good comfort ; [we]422-we watch the flock of [the great shepherd]423-the great shepherd , " said [the sexton]357-the sexton to [[his]357-the sexton wife]358-his wife . Then [he]357-the sexton turned to [me]423-the great shepherd . "[423-the great shepherd] Didst [thou]424-thou not find the air of [the place]2672-the place pure and sweet when [thou]424-thou enteredst it ? " [he]357-the sexton asked . "[423-the great shepherd] Yes ; but oh , so cold ! " [I]423-the great shepherd answered . "[423-the great shepherd] Then know , " [he]357-the sexton returned , and [his]357-the sexton voice was stern , "[423-the great shepherd] that [thou]424-thou who callest [thyself]426-thyself alive , hast brought into [this chamber]427-this chamber the odours of death , and its air will not be wholesome for [the sleepers]428-the sleepers until [thou]424-thou art gone from it ! " [They]422-we went farther into [the great chamber]2870-the great chamber , and [I]429-i was left alone in the moonlight with the dead . [I]429-i turned to escape . What a long way [I]429-i found it back through [the dead]2863-the dead ! At first [I]429-i was too angry to be afraid , but as [I]429-i grew calm , the still shapes grew terrible . At last , with loud offence to the gracious silence , [I]429-i ran , [I]429-i fled wildly , and , bursting out , flung - to the door behind [me]429-i . It closed with an awful silence . [I]429-i stood in pitch - darkness . Feeling about [me]429-i , [I]429-i found a door , opened it , and was aware of the dim light of a lamp . [I]429-i stood in [[my]429-i library]2872-my library , with the handle of the masked door in [my]429-i hand . Had [I]429-i come to [myself]429-i out of a vision?—or lost [myself]429-i by going back to one ? Which was the real — what [I]429-i now saw , or what [I]429-i had just ceased to see ? Could both be real , interpenetrating yet unmingling ? [I]429-i threw [myself]429-i on a couch , and fell asleep . In [the library]117-the library was one small window to the east , through which , at this time of the year , the first rays of the sun shone upon a mirror whence they were reflected on the masked door : when [I]429-i woke , there they shone , and thither [they]2874-they drew [my]429-i eyes . With the feeling that behind it must lie [the boundless chamber [I]429-i had left by that door]2875-the boundless chamber i had left by that door , [I]429-i sprang to [my]429-i feet , and opened it . The light , like an eager hound , shot before [me]429-i into [the closet]148-the closet , and pounced upon the gilded edges of a large book . "[429-i] What idiot , " [I]429-i cried , "[429-i] has put that book in the shelf the wrong way ? " But the gilded edges , reflecting the light a second time , flung it on a nest of drawers in a dark corner , and [I]429-i saw that one of them was half open . "[429-i] More meddling ! " [I]429-i cried , and went to close the drawer . It contained old papers , and seemed more than full , for it would not close . Taking the topmost one out , [I]429-i perceived that it was in [[my]429-i father]105-my father 's writing and of some length . The words on which first [my]429-i eyes fell , at once made [me]429-i eager to learn what it contained . [I]429-i carried it to [the library]117-the library , sat down in one of the western windows , and read what follows . [I]429-i AM filled with awe of what [I]429-i have to write . The sun is shining golden above [me]429-i ; [the sea]2879-the sea lies blue beneath [his]105-my father gaze ; [the same world]2880-the same world sends its growing things up to the sun , and its flying things into the air which [I]429-i have breathed from [my]429-i infancy ; but [I]429-i know the outspread splendour a passing show , and that at any moment it may , like the drop - scene of a stage , be lifted to reveal more wonderful things . Shortly after [[my]429-i father]105-my father 's death , [I]429-i was seated one morning in [the library]117-the library . [I]429-i had been , somewhat listlessly , regarding the portrait that hangs among the books , which [I]429-i knew only as that of [a distant ancestor]2883-a distant ancestor , and wishing [I]429-i could learn something of its original . Then [I]429-i had taken a book from the shelves and begun to read . Glancing up from it , [I]429-i saw coming toward [me]429-i — not between [me]429-i and the door , but between [me]429-i and the portrait — [a thin pale man in rusty black]2884-a thin pale man in rusty black . [He]2884-a thin pale man in rusty black looked sharp and eager , and had a notable nose , at once reminding [me]429-i of [a certain jug [[my]429-i sisters]2886-my sisters used to call [Mr. Crow]38-mr. crow]2885-a certain jug my sisters used to call mr. crow . "[429-i] Finding [myself]0-i in [[your]429-i vicinity]430-your vicinity , [Mr. Vane]27-mr. vane , [I]0-i have given [myself]0-i the pleasure of calling , " [he]431-your honoured grandfather said , in a peculiar but not disagreeable voice . "[0-i] [[Your]429-i honoured grandfather]431-your honoured grandfather treated [me]0-i — [I]0-i may say it without presumption — as [a friend]432-a friend , having known [me]0-i from childhood as [[[his]431-your honoured grandfather father]433-his father 's librarian]434-his father 's librarian . " It did not strike [me]434-his father 's librarian at the time how old [the man]2887-the man must be . "[434-his father 's librarian] May [I]0-i ask where [you]0-i live now , [Mr. Crow]38-mr. crow ? " [I]429-i said . [He]38-mr. crow smiled an amused smile . "[429-i] [You]429-i nearly hit [my]0-i name , " [he]38-mr. crow rejoined , "[429-i] which shows the family insight . [You]429-i have seen [me]0-i before , but only once , and could not then have heard it ! " "[429-i] Where was that ? " "[429-i] In [this very room]435-this very room . [You]0-i were quite [a child]106-a child , however ! " [I]106-a child could not be sure that [I]106-a child remembered [him]38-mr. crow , but for a moment [I]106-a child fancied [I]106-a child did , and [I]106-a child begged [him]38-mr. crow to set [me]106-a child right as to [his]38-mr. crow name . "[106-a child] There is such a thing as remembering without recognising the memory in it , " [he]38-mr. crow remarked . "[106-a child] For [my]0-i name — which [you]429-i have near enough — it used to be [Raven]24-mr. raven . " [I]24-mr. raven had heard the name , for marvellous tales had brought it [me]24-mr. raven . "[24-mr. raven] It is very kind of [you]0-i to come and see [me]0-i , " [I]0-i said . "[0-i] Will [you]0-i not sit down ? " [He]38-mr. crow seated [himself]38-mr. crow at once . "[0-i] [You]429-i knew [[my]0-i father]105-my father , then , [I]0-i presume ? " "[105-my father] [I]0-i knew [him]105-my father , " [he]38-mr. crow answered with a curious smile , "[105-my father] but [he]105-my father did not care about [my]0-i acquaintance , and [we]438-we never met.—That [gentleman]439-gentleman , however , " [he]38-mr. crow added , pointing to the portrait , "[439-gentleman] — [old Sir Up'ard]39-old sir up'ard , [[his]105-my father people]440-his people called [him,—was]105-my father in [his]105-my father day [a friend of [mine]0-i yet more intimate than ever [[your]442-your grandfather]443-your grandfather became]441-a friend of mine yet more intimate than ever your grandfather became . " Then at length [I]0-i began to think the interview a strange one . But in truth it was hardly stranger that [[my]0-i visitor]2888-my visitor should remember [Sir Upward]25-sir upward , than that [he]25-sir upward should have been [[[my]0-i great]2889-my great - grandfather 's librarian]2890-my great - grandfather 's librarian ! "[0-i] [I]0-i owe [him]105-my father much , " [he]105-my father continued ; "[0-i] for , although [I]0-i had read many more books than [he]105-my father , yet , through the special direction of [his]105-my father studies , [he]105-my father was able to inform [me]0-i of a certain relation of modes which [I]0-i should never have discovered of [myself]0-i , and could hardly have learned from [any one else]444-any one else . " "[105-my father] Would [you]0-i mind telling [me]0-i all about that ? " [I]0-i said . "[0-i] By no means — as much at least as [I]0-i am able : there are not such things as wilful secrets , " [he]105-my father answered — and went on . "[0-i] [That closet]445-that closet held [[his]105-my father library]446-his library — a hundred manuscripts or so , for printing was not then invented . One morning [I]0-i sat there , working at a catalogue of them , when [he]105-my father looked in at the door , and said , ` Come . ' [I]0-i laid down [my]0-i pen and followed [him]105-my father — across [the great hall]447-the great hall , down a steep rough descent , and along [an underground passage]448-an underground passage to [a tower [he]105-my father had lately built]449-a tower he had lately built , consisting of a stair and [a room at the top of [it]449-a tower he had lately built]450-a room at the top of it . The door of [this room]451-this room had a tremendous lock , which [he]105-my father undid with the smallest key [I]0-i ever saw . [I]0-i had scarcely crossed the threshold after [him]105-my father , when , to [my]0-i eyes , [he]105-my father began to dwindle , and grew less and less . All at once [my]0-i vision seemed to come right , and [I]0-i saw that [he]105-my father was moving swiftly away from [me]0-i . In a minute more [he]105-my father was the merest speck in the distance , with [the tops of [blue mountains]453-blue mountains beyond [him]105-my father]452-the tops of blue mountains beyond him , clear against a sky of paler blue . [I]0-i recognised [the country]454-the country , for [I]0-i had gone [there]204-there and come again many a time , although [I]0-i had never known this way to [it]454-the country . " Many years after , when [the tower]2891-the tower had long disappeared , [I]0-i taught [one of [[his]105-my father descendants]2893-his descendants]2892-one of his descendants what [Sir Upward]25-sir upward had taught [me]0-i ; and now and then to this day [I]0-i use [[your]105-my father house]2723-your house when [I]0-i want to go the nearest way [home]2676-home . [I]0-i must indeed — without [your]105-my father leave , for which [I]0-i ask [your]105-my father pardon — have by this time well established a right of way through it — not from front to back , but from bottom to top ! "[0-i] " [You]105-my father would have [me]0-i then understand , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " that [you]24-mr. raven go through [[my]0-i house]2896-my house into [another world]2897-another world , heedless of disparting space ? "[0-i] " That [I]180-the old librarian go through it is an incontrovertible acknowledgement of space , "[180-the old librarian] returned [the old librarian]180-the old librarian . " Please do not quibble , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , "[0-i] [I]0-i rejoined . " Please to take [my]0-i question as [you]24-mr. raven know [I]0-i mean it . "[0-i] " There is in [[your]24-mr. raven house]2723-your house a door , one step through which carries [me]0-i into [a world very much another than this]2899-a world very much another than this . "[0-i] " A better ? "[0-i] " Not throughout ; but so much another that most of its physical , and many of its mental laws are different from those of [this world]226-this world . As for moral laws , they must everywhere be fundamentally the same . "[0-i] " [You]24-mr. raven try [my]0-i power of belief ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " [You]24-mr. raven take [me]0-i for [a madman]2901-a madman , probably ? "[0-i] " [You]24-mr. raven do not look like [one]2690-one . "[0-i] " [A liar]2903-a liar then ? "[0-i] " [You]24-mr. raven give [me]0-i no ground to think [you]24-mr. raven such . "[0-i] " Only [you]24-mr. raven do not believe [me]0-i ? "[0-i] " [I]0-i will go out of that door with [you]457-he if [you]457-he like : [I]0-i believe in [you]457-he enough to risk the attempt . "[0-i] " The blunder all [[my]457-he children]2904-my children make ! "[457-he] [he]457-he murmured . " The only door out is the door in ! "[457-he] [I]0-i began to think [he]457-he must be crazy . [He]457-he sat silent for a moment , [his]457-he head resting on [his]457-he hand , [his]457-he elbow on the table , and [his]457-he eyes on the books before [him]457-he . " A book , "[457-he] [he]457-he said louder , " is a door in , and therefore a door out.—I see [old Sir Up'ard]39-old sir up'ard , "[457-he] [he]457-he went on , closing [his]457-he eyes , " and [my]457-he heart swells with love to him:—what world is [he]457-he in ? "[457-he] " [The world of [your]457-he heart]2905-the world of your heart ! "[0-i] [I]0-i replied ; " — that is , the idea of [him]457-he is there . "[457-he] " There is one world then at least on which [[your]457-he hall]2906-your hall - door does not open ? "[457-he] " [I]457-he grant [you]0-i so much ; but the things in [that world]309-that world are not things to have and to hold . "[457-he] " Think a little farther , "[457-he] [he]457-he rejoined : " did anything ever become [yours]0-i , except by getting into that world?—The thought is beyond [you]0-i , however , at present!—I tell [you]0-i there are more worlds , and more doors to them , than [you]0-i will think of in many years ! "[457-he] [He]457-he rose , left [the library]117-the library , crossed [the hall]185-the hall , and went straight up to [the garret]460-the garret , familiar evidently with every turn . [I]0-i followed , studying [his]457-he back . [His]457-he hair hung down long and dark , straight and glossy . [His]457-he coat was wide and reached to [his]457-he heels . [His]457-he shoes seemed too large for [him]457-he . In [the garret]460-the garret a light came through at the edges of the great roofing slabs , and showed [us]462-we parts where was no flooring , and [we]462-we must step from joist to joist : in the middle of [one of [these spaces]464-these spaces]463-one of these spaces rose a partition , with a door : through it [I]0-i followed [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven into [a small , obscure chamber , whose top contracted as it rose , and went slanting through the roof]465-a small , obscure chamber , whose top contracted as it rose , and went slanting through the roof . " That is the door [I]457-he spoke of , "[457-he] [he]457-he said , pointing to an oblong mirror that stood on the floor and leaned against the wall . [I]0-i went in front of [it]466-it , and saw [our]462-we figures dimly reflected in its dusty face . There was something about it that made [me]0-i uneasy . It looked old - fashioned and neglected , but , notwithstanding its ordinary seeming , the eagle , perched with outstretched wings on the top , appeared threatful . " As a mirror , "[245-the librarian] said [the librarian]245-the librarian , " it has grown dingy with age ; but that is no matter : [its]466-it doorness depends on the light . "[245-the librarian] " Light ! "[0-i] [I]0-i rejoined ; " there is no light here ! "[0-i] [He]457-he did not answer [me]0-i , but began to pull at a little chain on the opposite wall . [I]0-i heard a creaking : the top of [the chamber]208-the chamber was turning slowly round . [He]457-he ceased pulling , looked at [his]457-he watch , and began to pull again . " [We]462-we arrive almost to the moment ! "[457-he] [he]457-he said ; " it is on the very stroke of noon ! "[457-he] The top went creaking and revolving for a minute or so . Then [he]457-he pulled two other chains , now this , now that , and returned to the first . A moment more and [the chamber]208-the chamber grew much clearer : a patch of sunlight had fallen upon a mirror on the wall opposite that against which the other leaned , and on the dust [I]0-i saw the path of the reflected rays to the mirror on the ground . But from the latter none were returned ; they seemed to go clean through ; there was nowhere in [the chamber]208-the chamber a second patch of light ! " Where are the sunrays gone ? "[0-i] [I]0-i cried . " That [I]0-i can not tell , "[0-i] returned [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven ; " — back , perhaps , to where [they]2908-they came from first . [They]2908-they now belong , [I]457-he fancy , to a sense not yet developed in [us]471-us . "[457-he] [He]457-he then talked of the relations of mind to matter , and of senses to qualities , in a way [I]0-i could only a little understand , whence [he]457-he went on to yet stranger things which [I]0-i could not at all apprehend . [He]457-he spoke much about dimensions , telling [me]0-i there were many more than three , some of them concerned with powers which were indeed in [us]471-us , but of which as yet [we]471-us knew absolutely nothing . [His]457-he words , however , [I]0-i confess , took little more hold of [me]0-i than the light did of the mirror , for [I]0-i thought [he]457-he hardly knew what [he]457-he was saying . Suddenly [I]0-i was aware that [our]471-us forms had gone from the mirror , which seemed full of a white mist . As [I]0-i gazed [I]0-i saw , growing gradually visible beyond the mist , the tops of [a range of mountains]472-a range of mountains , which became clearer and clearer . Soon the mist vanished entirely , uncovering the face of [a wide heath]473-a wide heath , on which , at some distance , was the figure of [a man moving swiftly away]474-a man moving swiftly away . [I]0-i turned to address [[my]0-i companion]475-my companion ; [he]457-he was no longer by [my]0-i side . [I]0-i looked again at [the form in the mirror]476-the form in the mirror , and recognised the wide coat flying , the black hair lifting in a wind that did not touch [me]0-i . [I]0-i rushed in terror from [the place]2672-the place . [I]0-i LAID the manuscript down , consoled to find that [[my]0-i father]105-my father had had a peep into [that mysterious world]479-that mysterious world , and that [he]105-my father knew [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven . Then [I]0-i remembered that [I]0-i had never heard the cause or any circumstance of [[my]0-i father]105-my father 's death , and began to believe that [he]105-my father must at last have followed [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven , and not come back ; whereupon [I]0-i speedily grew ashamed of [my]0-i flight . What wondrous facts might [I]0-i not by this time have gathered concerning life and death , and wide regions beyond ordinary perception ! Assuredly [the Ravens]481-the ravens were [good people]482-good people , and a night in [[their]481-the ravens house]483-their house would nowise have hurt [me]0-i ! [They]481-the ravens were doubtless strange , but it was faculty in which [the one]484-the one was peculiar , and beauty in which the other was marvellous ! And [I]0-i had not believed in [them]481-the ravens ! had treated [them]481-the ravens as unworthy of [my]0-i confidence , as harbouring a design against [me]0-i ! The more [I]0-i thought of [my]0-i behaviour to [them]481-the ravens , the more disgusted [I]0-i became with [myself]0-i . Why should [I]0-i have feared [such dead]485-such dead ? To share [their]481-the ravens holy rest was an honour of which [I]0-i had proved [myself]0-i unworthy ! What harm could [that sleeping king]486-that sleeping king , [that lady with the wound in [her]486-that sleeping king palm]487-that lady with the wound in her palm , have done [me]0-i ? [I]0-i fell a - longing after the sweet and stately stillness of [their]481-the ravens two countenances , and wept . Weeping [I]0-i threw [myself]0-i on a couch , and suddenly fell asleep . As suddenly [I]0-i woke , feeling as if [some one]2727-some one had called [me]0-i . [The house]112-the house was still as [an empty church]490-an empty church . A blackbird was singing on [the lawn]268-the lawn . [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , " [I]0-i will go and tell [them]481-the ravens [I]0-i am ashamed , and will do whatever [they]481-the ravens would have [me]0-i do ! "[0-i] [I]0-i rose , and went straight up the stairs to [the garret]460-the garret . [The wooden chamber]493-the wooden chamber was just as when first [I]0-i saw it , the mirror dimly reflecting everything before it . It was nearly noon , and the sun would be a little higher than when first [I]0-i came : [I]0-i must raise the hood a little , and adjust the mirrors accordingly ! If [I]0-i had but been in time to see [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven do it ! [I]0-i pulled the chains , and let the light fall on the first mirror . [I]0-i turned then to the other : there were the shapes of the former vision — distinguishable indeed , but tremulous like a landscape in a pool ruffled by " a small pipling wind ! "[0-i] [I]0-i touched the glass ; it was impermeable . Suspecting polarisation as the thing required , [I]0-i shifted and shifted the mirrors , changing their relation , until at last , in a great degree , so far as [I]0-i was concerned , by chance , things came right between [them]494-them , and [I]0-i saw [the mountains]495-the mountains blue and steady and clear . [I]0-i stepped forward , and [my]0-i feet were among the heather . All [I]0-i knew of the way to [the cottage]340-the cottage was that [we]497-we had gone through [a pine- forest]498-a pine- forest . [I]0-i passed through many thickets and [several small fir - woods]499-several small fir - woods , continually fancying afresh that [I]0-i recognised something of [the country]454-the country ; but [I]0-i had come upon [no forest]501-no forest , and now the sun was near the horizon , and the air had begun to grow chill with the coming winter , when , to [my]0-i delight , [I]0-i saw a little black object coming toward [me]0-i : it was indeed the raven ! [I]0-i hastened to meet [him]502-you . " [I]0-i beg [your]502-you pardon , [sir]2678-sir , for [my]0-i rudeness last night , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " Will [you]502-you take [me]0-i with [you]502-you now ? [I]0-i heartily confess [I]0-i do not deserve it . "[0-i] " Ah ! "[502-you] [he]502-you returned , and looked up . Then , after a brief pause , " [[My]502-you wife]2760-my wife does not expect [you]0-i to - night , "[502-you] [he]502-you said . " [She]2760-my wife regrets that [we]2911-we at all encouraged [your]0-i staying last week . "[502-you] " Take [me]0-i to [her]2760-my wife that [I]0-i may tell [her]2760-my wife how sorry [I]0-i am , "[0-i] [I]0-i begged humbly . " It is of no use , "[502-you] [he]502-you answered . " [Your]0-i night was not come then , or [you]0-i would not have left [us]2911-we . It is not come now , and [I]502-you can not show [you]0-i the way . [The dead]2863-the dead were rejoicing under [their]2863-the dead daisies — [they]2863-the dead all lie among the roots of the flowers of heaven — at the thought of [your]0-i delight when the winter should be past , and the morning with its birds come : ere [you]0-i left [them]2863-the dead , [they]2863-the dead shivered in [their]2863-the dead beds . When the spring of [the universe]266-the universe arrives,—but that can not be for ages yet ! how many , [I]502-you do not know — and do not care to know . "[502-you] " Tell [me]502-you one thing , [I]502-you beg of [you]502-you , [Mr. Raven]24-mr. raven : is [[my]502-you father]105-my father with [you]502-you ? Have [you]502-you seen [him]105-my father since [he]105-my father left [the world]108-the world ? "[502-you] " Yes ; [he]105-my father is with [us]2916-us , fast asleep . That was [he]105-my father [you]502-you saw with [his]105-my father arm on the coverlet , [his]105-my father hand half closed . "[502-you] " Why did [you]502-you not tell [me]502-you ? That [I]502-you should have been so near [him]105-my father , and not know ! "[502-you] " And turn [your]502-you back on [him]105-my father ! "[233-the raven] corrected [the raven]233-the raven . " [I]233-the raven would have lain down at once had [I]233-the raven known ! "[233-the raven] " [I]233-the raven doubt it . Had [you]233-the raven been ready to lie down , [you]233-the raven would have known [him!—Old Sir Up'ard]39-old sir up'ard , "[233-the raven] [he]233-the raven went on , " and [[your]233-the raven twice great - grandfather]2917-your twice great - grandfather , both are up and away long ago . [[Your]233-the raven great - grandfather]2918-your great - grandfather has been with [us]2919-us for many a year ; [I]233-the raven think [he]2918-your great - grandfather will soon begin to stir . [You]233-the raven saw [him]2918-your great - grandfather last night , though of course [you]233-the raven did not know [him]2918-your great - grandfather . "[233-the raven] " Why of course ? "[233-the raven] " Because [he]2918-your great - grandfather is so much nearer waking than [you]233-the raven . [No one who will not sleep]2920-no one who will not sleep can ever wake . "[233-the raven] " [I]0-i can not understand [you]233-the raven ! "[0-i] " Naturally not . Neither do [I]233-the raven understand [you]233-the raven ; [I]233-the raven can read neither [your]233-the raven heart nor [your]233-the raven face . When [[my]233-the raven wife]2760-my wife and [I]233-the raven do not understand [[our]2925-we children]2926-our children , it is because there is not enough of [them]2926-our children to be understood . [God]33-god alone can understand foolishness . "[233-the raven] " Then , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , feeling naked and very worthless , " will [you]233-the raven be so good as show [me]0-i the nearest way [home]2676-home ? There are more ways than one , [I]0-i know , for [I]0-i have gone by two already . "[0-i] " There are indeed many ways . "[233-the raven] " Tell [me]233-the raven , please , how to recognise the nearest . "[233-the raven] " [I]233-the raven can not , "[233-the raven] answered [the raven]233-the raven ; " [you]233-the raven and [I]233-the raven use the same words with different meanings . [We]2925-we are often unable to tell [people]2775-people what [they]2775-people need to know , because [they]2775-people want to know something else , and would therefore only misunderstand what [we]2925-we said . [Home]2676-home is ever so far away in the palm of [your]233-the raven hand , and how to get [there]204-there it is of no use to tell [you]233-the raven . But [you]233-the raven will get there ; [you]233-the raven must get there ; [you]233-the raven have to get [there]204-there . [Everybody who is not at home]2932-everybody who is not at home , has to go [home]2676-home . [You]233-the raven thought [you]233-the raven were at [home]2676-home where [I]233-the raven found [you]233-the raven : if that had been [[your]233-the raven home]2935-your home , [you]233-the raven could not have left [it]2676-home . [Nobody]149-nobody can leave [home]2676-home . And [nobody]149-nobody ever was or ever will be at [home]2676-home without having gone [there]204-there . "[233-the raven] " [Enigma]40-enigma treading on enigma ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed . " [I]0-i did not come here to be asked riddles . "[0-i] " No ; but [you]0-i came , and found the riddles waiting for [you]0-i ! Indeed [you]0-i are [yourself]0-i the only riddle . What [you]0-i call riddles are truths , and seem riddles because [you]0-i are not true . "[233-the raven] " Worse and worse ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried . " And [you]0-i must answer the riddles ! "[506-he] [he]506-he continued . " [They]2941-they will go on asking [themselves]2941-they until [you]0-i understand [yourself]0-i . [The universe]266-the universe is a riddle trying to get out , and [you]0-i are holding [your]0-i door hard against it . "[506-he] " Will [you]506-he not in pity tell [me]233-the raven what [I]233-the raven am to do — where [I]233-the raven must go ? "[233-the raven] " How should [I]507-i tell [your]0-i to - do , or the way to it ? "[507-i] " If [I]506-he am not to go [home]2676-home , at least direct [me]506-he to some of [[my]506-he kind]2944-my kind . "[506-he] " [I]507-i do not know of any . [The beings most like [you]0-i]2945-the beings most like you are in that direction . "[507-i] [He]507-i pointed with [his]507-i beak . [I]0-i could see nothing but the setting sun , which blinded [me]0-i . " Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i said bitterly , " [I]0-i can not help feeling hardly treated — taken from [[my]0-i home]2946-my home , abandoned in [a strange world]2947-a strange world , and refused instruction as to where [I]0-i am to go or what [I]0-i am to do ! "[0-i] " [You]0-i forget , "[233-the raven] said [the raven]233-the raven , " that , when [I]233-the raven brought [you]0-i and [you]0-i declined [my]233-the raven hospitality , [you]0-i reached what [you]0-i call [home]2676-home in safety : now [you]0-i are come of [yourself]0-i ! Good night . "[233-the raven] [He]233-the raven turned and walked slowly away , with [his]233-the raven beak toward the ground . [I]0-i stood dazed . It was true [I]0-i had come of [myself]0-i , but had [I]0-i not come with intent of atonement ? [My]0-i heart was sore , and in [my]0-i brain was neither quest nor purpose , hope nor desire . [I]0-i gazed after the raven , and would have followed [him]233-the raven , but felt it useless . All at once [he]233-the raven pounced on a spot , throwing the whole weight of [his]233-the raven body on [his]233-the raven bill , and for some moments dug vigorously . Then with a flutter of [his]233-the raven wings [he]233-the raven threw back [his]233-the raven head , and something shot from [his]233-the raven bill , cast high in the air . That moment the sun set , and the air at once grew very dusk , but the something opened into a soft radiance , and came pulsing toward [me]0-i like a fire - fly , but with a much larger and a yellower light . It flew over [my]0-i head . [I]0-i turned and followed it . Here [I]0-i interrupt [my]0-i narrative to remark that it involves a constant struggle to say what can not be said with even an approach to precision , the things recorded being , in [their]509-their nature and in that of the creatures concerned in [them]509-their , so inexpressibly different from any possible events of this economy , that [I]0-i can present [them]509-their only by giving , in the forms and language of life in [this world]226-this world , the modes in which [they]509-their affected [me]0-i — not the things [themselves]509-their , but the feelings [they]509-their woke in [me]0-i . Even this much , however , [I]0-i do with a continuous and abiding sense of failure , finding it impossible to present more than one phase of a multitudinously complicated significance , or one concentric sphere of a graduated embodiment . A single thing would sometimes seem to be and mean many things , with an uncertain identity at the heart of them , which kept constantly altering [their]509-their look . [I]0-i am indeed often driven to set down what [I]0-i know to be but a clumsy and doubtful representation of the mere feeling aimed at , none of the communicating media of [this world]226-this world being fit to convey it , in its peculiar strangeness , with even an approach to clearness or certainty . Even to one who knew [the region]512-the region better than [myself]0-i , [I]0-i should have no assurance of transmitting the reality of [my]0-i experience in it . While without a doubt , for instance , that [I]0-i was actually regarding a scene of activity , [I]0-i might be , at the same moment , in [my]0-i consciousness aware that [I]0-i was perusing a metaphysical argument . AS the air grew black and the winter closed swiftly around [me]0-i , the fluttering fire blazed out more luminous , and arresting its flight , hovered waiting . So soon as [I]0-i came under its radiance , it flew slowly on , lingering now and then above spots where the ground was rocky . Every time [I]0-i looked up , it seemed to have grown larger , and at length gave [me]0-i an attendant shadow . Plainly a bird - butterfly , it flew with a certain swallowy double . Its wings were very large , nearly square , and flashed all the colours of the rainbow . Wondering at their splendour , [I]0-i became so absorbed in their beauty that [I]0-i stumbled over a low rock , and lay stunned . When [I]0-i came to [myself]0-i , the creature was hovering over [my]0-i head , radiating the whole chord of light , with multitudinous gradations and some kinds of colour [I]0-i had never before seen . [I]0-i rose and went on , but , unable to take [my]0-i eyes off the shining thing to look to [my]0-i steps , [I]0-i struck [my]0-i foot against a stone . Fearing then another fall , [I]0-i sat down to watch the little glory , and a great longing awoke in [me]0-i to have it in [my]0-i hand . To [my]0-i unspeakable delight , it began to sink toward [me]0-i . Slowly at first , then swiftly it sank , growing larger as it came nearer . [I]0-i felt as if the treasure of [the universe]266-the universe were giving itself to [me]0-i — put out [my]0-i hand , and had it . But the instant [I]0-i took it , its light went out ; all was dark as pitch ; a dead book with boards outspread lay cold and heavy in [my]0-i hand . [I]0-i threw it in the air — only to hear it fall among the heather . Burying [my]0-i face in [my]0-i hands , [I]0-i sat in motionless misery . But the cold grew so bitter that , fearing to be frozen , [I]0-i got up . The moment [I]0-i was on [my]0-i feet , a faint sense of light awoke in [me]0-i . " Is it coming to life ? "[0-i] [I]0-i cried , and a great pang of hope shot through [me]0-i . Alas , no ! it was the edge of a moon peering up keen and sharp over a level horizon ! [She]514-her brought [me]0-i light — but no guidance ! [She]514-her would not hover over [me]0-i , would not wait on [my]0-i faltering steps ! [She]514-her could but offer [me]0-i an ignorant choice ! With a full face [she]514-her rose , and [I]0-i began to see a little about [me]0-i . Westward of [her]514-her , and not far from [me]0-i , [a range of low hills]515-a range of low hills broke the horizon - line ; [I]0-i set out for [it]515-a range of low hills . But what a night [I]0-i had to pass ere [I]0-i reached [it]515-a range of low hills ! The moon seemed to know something , for [she]514-her stared at [me]0-i oddly . [Her]514-her look was indeed icy - cold , but full of interest , or at least curiosity . [She]514-her was not the same moon [I]0-i had known on [the earth]2702-the earth ; [her]514-her face was strange to [me]0-i , and [her]514-her light yet stranger . Perhaps it came from an unknown sun ! Every time [I]0-i looked up , [I]0-i found [her]514-her staring at [me]0-i with all [her]514-her might ! At first [I]0-i was annoyed , as at the rudeness of [a fellow creature]517-a fellow creature ; but soon [I]0-i saw or fancied a certain wondering pity in [her]514-her gaze : why was [I]0-i out in [her]514-her night ? Then first [I]0-i knew what an awful thing it was to be awake in [the universe]266-the universe : [I]0-i was , and could not help it ! As [I]0-i walked , [my]0-i feet lost the heather , and trod a bare spongy soil , something like dry , powdery peat . To [my]0-i dismay it gave a momentary heave under [me]0-i ; then presently [I]0-i saw what seemed the ripple of an earthquake running on before [me]0-i , shadowy in the low moon . It passed into the distance ; but , while yet [I]0-i stared after it , a single wave rose up , and came slowly toward [me]0-i . A yard or two away it burst , and from it , with a scramble and a bound , issued an animal like a tiger . About [his]514-her mouth and ears hung clots of mould , and [his]514-her eyes winked and flamed as [he]514-her rushed at [me]0-i , showing [his]514-her white teeth in a soundless snarl . [I]0-i stood fascinated , unconscious of either courage or fear . [He]514-her turned [his]514-her head to the ground , and plunged into it . " That moon is affecting [my]0-i brain , "[0-i] [I]0-i said as [I]0-i resumed [my]0-i journey . " What life can be here but the phantasmic — the stuff of which dreams are made ? [I]0-i am indeed walking in a vain show ! "[0-i] Thus [I]0-i strove to keep [my]0-i heart above the waters of fear , nor knew that [she]519-she whom [I]0-i distrusted was indeed [my]0-i defence from the realities [I]0-i took for phantoms : [her]519-she light controlled [the monsters]520-the monsters , else had [I]0-i scarce taken a second step on [the hideous ground]521-the hideous ground . " [I]0-i will not be appalled by that which only seems ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , yet felt it a terrible thing to walk on [a sea]522-a sea where such fishes disported themselves below . With that , a step or two from [me]0-i , the head of a worm began to come slowly out of [the earth]2702-the earth , as big as that of a polar bear and much resembling it , with a white mane to its red neck . The drawing wriggles with which its huge length extricated itself were horrible , yet [I]0-i dared not turn [my]0-i eyes from them . The moment its tail was free , it lay as if exhausted , wallowing in feeble effort to burrow again . " Does it live on the dead , "[0-i] [I]0-i wondered , " and is it unable to hurt the living ? If [they]524-their scent [their]524-their prey and come out , why do [they]524-their leave [me]0-i unharmed ? "[0-i] [I]0-i know now it was that the moon paralysed [them]524-their . All the night through as [I]0-i walked , hideous creatures , [no two alike]525-no two alike , threatened [me]0-i . In some of [them]524-their , beauty of colour enhanced loathliness of shape : one large serpent was covered from head to distant tail with feathers of glorious hues . [I]0-i became at length so accustomed to [their]524-their hurtless menaces that [I]0-i fell to beguiling the way with the invention of monstrosities , never suspecting that [I]0-i owed each moment of life to the staring moon . Though hers was no primal radiance , it so hampered the evil things , that [I]0-i walked in safety . For light is yet light , if but the last of a countless series of reflections ! How swiftly would not [my]0-i feet have carried [me]0-i over [the restless soil]526-the restless soil , had [I]0-i known that , if still within [their]524-their range when [her]527-her lamp ceased to shine on the cursed spot , [I]0-i should that moment be at the mercy of such as had no mercy , the centre of a writhing heap of hideousness , [every individual of it as terrible as before it had but seemed]528-every individual of it as terrible as before it had but seemed ! [Fool of ignorance]529-fool of ignorance , [I]0-i watched the descent of [the weary , solemn , anxious moon]530-the weary , solemn , anxious moon down the widening vault above [me]0-i , with no worse uneasiness than the dread of losing [my]0-i way — where as yet [I]0-i had indeed no way to lose . [I]0-i was drawing near [the hills]531-the hills [I]0-i had made [my]0-i goal , and [she]527-her was now not far from [their]531-the hills sky - line , when the soundless wallowing ceased , and the burrow lay motionless and bare . Then [I]0-i saw , slowly walking over [the light soil]532-the light soil , the form of [a woman]344-a woman . A white mist floated about [her]527-her , now assuming , now losing to reassume the shape of a garment , as it gathered to [her]527-her or was blown from [her]527-her by a wind that dogged [her]527-her steps . [She]527-her was beautiful , but with such a pride at once and misery on [her]527-her countenance that [I]0-i could hardly believe what yet [I]0-i saw . Up and down [she]527-her walked , vainly endeavouring to lay hold of the mist and wrap it around [her]527-her . The eyes in the beautiful face were dead , and on [her]527-her left side was a dark spot , against which [she]527-her would now and then press [her]527-her hand , as if to stifle pain or sickness . [Her]527-her hair hung nearly to [her]527-her feet , and sometimes the wind would so mix it with the mist that [I]0-i could not distinguish the one from the other ; but when it fell gathering together again , it shone a pale gold in the moonlight . Suddenly pressing both hands on [her]527-her heart , [she]527-her fell to the ground , and the mist rose from [her]527-her and melted in the air . [I]0-i ran to [her]527-her . But [she]527-her began to writhe in such torture that [I]0-i stood aghast . A moment more and [her]527-her legs , hurrying from [her]527-her body , sped away serpents . From [her]527-her shoulders fled [her]527-her arms as in terror , serpents also . Then something flew up from [her]527-her like a bat , and when [I]0-i looked again , [she]527-her was gone . [The ground]534-the ground rose like the sea in a storm ; terror laid hold upon [me]0-i ; [I]0-i turned to [the hills]531-the hills and ran . [I]0-i was already on the slope of [[their]531-the hills base]536-their base , when the moon sank behind one of [their]531-the hills summits , leaving [me]0-i in its shadow . Behind [me]0-i rose a waste and sickening cry , as of frustrate desire — the only sound [I]0-i had heard since the fall of the dead butterfly ; it made [my]0-i heart shake like a flag in the wind . [I]0-i turned , saw many dark objects bounding after [me]0-i , and made for the crest of [a ridge on which the moon still shone]537-a ridge on which the moon still shone . [She]527-her seemed to linger there that [I]0-i might see to defend [myself]0-i . Soon [I]0-i came in sight of [her]527-her , and climbed the faster . Crossing the shadow of a rock , [I]0-i heard the creatures panting at [my]0-i heels . But just as [the foremost]538-the foremost threw [himself]538-the foremost upon [me]0-i with a snarl of greedy hate , [we]539-we rushed into the moon together . [She]527-her flashed out an angry light , and [he]538-the foremost fell from [me]0-i a bodiless blotch . [Strength]41-strength came to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i turned on the rest . But one by one as [they]540-they darted into the light , [they]540-they dropped with a howl ; and [I]0-i saw or fancied a strange smile on the round face above [me]0-i . [I]0-i climbed to [the top of [the ridge]542-the ridge]541-the top of the ridge : far away shone the moon , sinking to a low horizon . The air was pure and strong . [I]0-i descended a little way , found it warmer , and sat down to wait the dawn . The moon went below , and [the world]108-the world again was dark . [I]0-i FELL fast asleep , and when [I]0-i woke the sun was rising . [I]0-i went to the top again , and looked back : [the hollow [I]0-i had crossed]544-the hollow i had crossed in the moonlight lay without sign of life . Could it be that [the calm expanse before [me]0-i]545-the calm expanse before me swarmed with creatures of devouring greed ? [I]0-i turned and looked over [the land through which]546-the land through which [my]0-i way must lie . [It]546-the land through which seemed [a wide desert , with a patch of a different colour in the distance that might be [a forest]2846-a forest]547-a wide desert , with a patch of a different colour in the distance that might be a forest . Sign of presence , human or animal , was none — smoke nor dust nor shadow of cultivation . Not a cloud floated in the clear heaven ; no thinnest haze curtained any segment of [its]546-the land through which circling rim . [I]0-i descended , and set out for [the imaginable forest]549-the imaginable forest : something alive might be there ; on this side of [it]549-the imaginable forest could not well be anything ! When [I]0-i reached [the plain]550-the plain , [I]0-i found [it]550-the plain , as far as [my]0-i sight could go , of rock , here flat and channeled , there humped and pinnacled — evidently the wide bed of [a vanished river]551-a vanished river , scored by innumerable water - runs , without a trace of moisture in them . Some of the channels bore a dry moss , and some of the rocks a few lichens almost as hard as themselves . The air , once " filled with pleasant noise of waters , "[0-i] was silent as death . It took [me]0-i the whole day to reach [the patch,—which]552-the patch,—which [I]0-i found indeed [a forest]2846-a forest — but not a rudiment of brook or runnel had [I]0-i crossed ! Yet through the glowing noon [I]0-i seemed haunted by an aural mirage , hearing so plainly the voice of many waters that [I]0-i could hardly believe the opposing testimony of [my]0-i eyes . The sun was approaching the horizon when [I]0-i left [the river - bed]554-the river - bed , and entered [the forest]314-the forest . Sunk below the tree - tops , and sending [his]556-his rays between their pillar - like boles , [he]556-his revealed a world of blessed shadows waiting to receive [me]0-i . [I]0-i had expected a pine - wood , but here were trees of many sorts , some with strong resemblances to trees [I]0-i knew , others with marvellous differences from any [I]0-i had ever seen . [I]0-i threw [myself]0-i beneath the boughs of what seemed a eucalyptus in blossom : its flowers had a hard calyx much resembling a skull , the top of which rose like a lid to let the froth - like bloom - brain overfoam its cup . From beneath the shadow of its falchion - leaves [my]0-i eyes went wandering into deep after deep of [the forest]314-the forest . Soon , however , [its]314-the forest doors and windows began to close , shutting up aisle and [corridor]558-corridor and roomier glade . The night was about [me]0-i , and instant and sharp the cold . Again what a night [I]0-i found it ! How shall [I]0-i make [[my]0-i reader]223-my reader share with [me]0-i its wild ghostiness ? The tree under which [I]0-i lay rose high before it branched , but the boughs of it bent so low that they seemed ready to shut [me]0-i in as [I]0-i leaned against the smooth stem , and let [my]0-i eyes wander through the brief twilight of [the vanishing forest]560-the vanishing forest . Presently , to [my]0-i listless roving gaze , the varied outlines of the clumpy foliage began to assume or imitate — say rather suggest other shapes than [their]561-their own . A light wind began to blow ; it set the boughs of a neighbour tree rocking , and all [their]561-their branches aswing , every twig and every leaf blending its individual motion with the sway of its branch and the rock of its bough . Among its leafy shapes was [a pack of wolves that struggled to break from a wizard]562-a pack of wolves that struggled to break from a wizard 's leash : greyhounds would not have strained so savagely ! [I]0-i watched [them]561-their with an interest that grew as the wind gathered force , and [their]561-their motions life . Another mass of foliage , larger and more compact , presented [my]0-i fancy with a group of horses ' heads and forequarters projecting caparisoned from [their]561-their stalls . [Their]561-their necks kept moving up and down , with an impatience that augmented as the growing wind broke their vertical rhythm with a wilder swaying from side to side . What heads [they]561-their were ! how gaunt , how strange!—several of [them]561-their bare skulls — one with the skin tight on its bones ! One had lost the under jaw and hung low , looking unutterably weary — but now and then hove high as if to ease the bit . Above [them]561-their , at the end of a branch , floated erect the form of [a woman]344-a woman , waving [her]344-a woman arms in imperious gesture . The definiteness of these and other leaf masses first surprised and then discomposed [me]0-i : what if [they]561-their should overpower [my]0-i brain with seeming reality ? But the twilight became darkness ; the wind ceased ; every shape was shut up in the night ; [I]0-i fell asleep . It was still dark when [I]0-i began to be aware of [a far - off , confused , rushing noise , mingled with faint cries]564-a far - off , confused , rushing noise , mingled with faint cries . It grew and grew until a tumult as of gathering multitudes filled the wood . On all sides at once the sounds drew nearer ; the spot where [I]0-i lay seemed the centre of a commotion that extended throughout [the forest]314-the forest . [I]0-i scarce moved hand or foot lest [I]0-i should betray [my]0-i presence to hostile things . The moon at length approached [the forest]314-the forest , and came slowly into [it]314-the forest : with [her]344-a woman first gleam the noises increased to a deafening uproar , and [I]0-i began to see dim shapes about [me]0-i . As [she]344-a woman ascended and grew brighter , the noises became yet louder , and the shapes clearer . A furious battle was raging around [me]0-i . Wild cries and roars of rage , shock of onset , struggle prolonged , all mingled with words articulate , surged in [my]0-i ears . Curses and credos , snarls and sneers , laughter and mockery , sacred names and howls of hate , came huddling in chaotic interpenetration . [Skeletons]42-skeletons and phantoms fought in maddest confusion . Swords swept through [the phantoms]567-the phantoms : they only shivered . Maces crashed on the skeletons , shattering them hideously : [not one]568-not one fell or ceased to fight , so long as a single joint held two bones together . Bones of [men]169-men and horses lay scattered and heaped ; grinding and crunching them under foot fought the skeletons . Everywhere charged the bone - gaunt white steeds ; everywhere on foot or on wind - blown misty battle - horses , raged and ravened and raved the indestructible spectres ; weapons and hoofs clashed and crushed ; while skeleton jaws and phantom - throats swelled the deafening tumult with the war - cry of every opinion , bad or good , that had bred strife , injustice , cruelty in [any world]570-any world . The holiest words went with the most hating blow . Lie - distorted truths flew hurtling in the wind of javelins and bones . Every moment [some one]2727-some one would turn against [[his]2727-some one comrades]572-his comrades , and fight more wildly than before , The Truth ! The Truth ! still [his]2727-some one cry . One [I]0-i noted who wheeled ever in a circle , and smote on all sides . Wearied out , [a pair]573-a pair would sit for a minute side by side , then rise and renew the fierce combat . [None]574-none stooped to comfort [the fallen]575-the fallen , or stepped wide to spare [him]575-the fallen . The moon shone till the sun rose , and all the night long [I]0-i had glimpses of [a woman moving at [her]344-a woman will above [the strife - tormented multitude]577-the strife - tormented multitude , now on this front now on that , one outstretched arm urging the fight , the other pressed against [her]344-a woman side]576-a woman moving at her will above the strife - tormented multitude , now on this front now on that , one outstretched arm urging the fight , the other pressed against her side . " [Ye]2949-ye are [men]169-men : slay [one another]2951-one another ! "[344-a woman] [she]344-a woman shouted . [I]0-i saw [her]344-a woman dead eyes and [her]344-a woman dark spot , and recalled what [I]0-i had seen the night before . Such was the battle of the dead , which [I]0-i saw and heard as [I]0-i lay under the tree . Just before sunrise , a breeze went through [the forest]314-the forest , and a voice cried , " Let [the dead]2863-the dead bury [their]2863-the dead dead ! "[575-the fallen] At the word [the contending thousands]579-the contending thousands dropped noiseless , and when the sun looked in , [he]575-the fallen saw never a bone , but here and there a withered branch . [I]0-i rose and resumed [my]0-i journey , through as quiet a wood as ever grew out of [the quiet earth]580-the quiet earth . For the wind of the morning had ceased when the sun appeared , and the trees were silent . Not a bird sang , not a squirrel , mouse , or weasel showed itself , not a belated moth flew athwart [my]0-i path . But as [I]0-i went [I]0-i kept watch over [myself]0-i , nor dared let [my]0-i eyes rest on any forest - shape . All the time [I]0-i seemed to hear faint sounds of mattock and spade and hurtling bones : any moment [my]0-i eyes might open on things [I]0-i would not see ! [Daylight prudence]43-daylight prudence muttered that perhaps , to appear , ten thousand phantoms awaited only [my]0-i consenting fancy . In the middle of the afternoon [I]0-i came out of [the wood]2922-the wood — to find before [me]0-i a second net of dry water - courses . [I]0-i thought at first that [I]0-i had wandered from [my]0-i attempted line , and reversed [my]0-i direction ; but [I]0-i soon saw it was not so , and concluded presently that [I]0-i had come to [another branch of [the same river - bed]583-the same river - bed]582-another branch of the same river - bed . [I]0-i began at once to cross [it]582-another branch of the same river - bed , and was in the bottom of a wide channel when the sun set . [I]0-i sat down to await the moon , and growing sleepy , stretched [myself]0-i on the moss . The moment [my]0-i head was down , [I]0-i heard the sounds of [rushing streams]584-rushing streams — all sorts of sweet watery noises . The veiled melody of the molten music sang [me]0-i into a dreamless sleep , and when [I]0-i woke the sun was already up , and [the wrinkled country]585-the wrinkled country widely visible . Covered with shadows it lay striped and mottled like the skin of some wild animal . As the sun rose the shadows diminished , and it seemed as if the rocks were re - absorbing the darkness that had oozed out of them during the night . Hitherto [I]0-i had loved [my]0-i Arab mare and [my]0-i books more , [I]0-i fear , than [live man]586-live man or [woman]377-woman ; now at length [my]0-i soul was athirst for a human presence , and [I]0-i longed even after those inhabitants of [this alien world]588-this alien world whom the raven had so vaguely described as nearest [my]0-i sort . With heavy yet hoping heart , and mind haunted by a doubt whether [I]0-i was going in any direction at all , [I]0-i kept wearily travelling " [north - west and by south]2953-north - west and by south . "[0-i] COMING , in one of the channels , upon what seemed a little shrub , [the outlying picket]589-the outlying picket , [I]0-i trusted , of [an army behind [it]585-the wrinkled country]590-an army behind it , [I]0-i knelt to look at [it]585-the wrinkled country closer . It bore a small fruit , which , as [I]0-i did not recognise it , [I]0-i feared to gather and eat . Little [I]0-i thought that [I]0-i was watched from behind the rocks by hundreds of eyes eager with the question whether [I]0-i would or would not take it . [I]0-i came to another plant somewhat bigger , then to another larger still , and at length to clumps of a like sort ; by which time [I]0-i saw that they were not shrubs but dwarf - trees . Before [I]0-i reached the bank of [this second branch of [the river - bed]554-the river - bed]591-this second branch of the river - bed , [I]0-i found the channels so full of them that it was with difficulty [I]0-i crossed such as [I]0-i could not jump . In one [I]0-i heard a great rush , as of a multitude of birds from an ivied wall , but saw nothing . [I]0-i came next to some large fruit - bearing trees , but what they bore looked coarse . [They]593-they stood on the edge of [a hollow , which evidently had once been the basin of [a lake]595-a lake]594-a hollow , which evidently had once been the basin of a lake . From the left [a forest]2846-a forest seemed to flow into and fill [it]594-a hollow , which evidently had once been the basin of a lake ; but while the trees above were of many sorts , those in [the hollow]597-the hollow were almost entirely fruit - bearing . [I]0-i went a few yards down [the slope of grass]598-the slope of grass mingled with moss , and stretched [myself]0-i upon [it]598-the slope of grass weary . A little farther down stood a tiny tree full of rosiest apples no bigger than small cherries , its top close to [my]0-i hand ; [I]0-i pulled and ate one of them . Finding it delicious , [I]0-i was in the act of taking another , when a sudden shouting of [children]599-children , mingled with laughter clear and sweet as tile music of [a brook]600-a brook , startled [me]0-i with delight . " [He]2954-he likes [our]2955-our apples ! [He]2954-he likes [our]2955-our apples ! [He]2954-he 's [a good giant]2956-a good giant ! [He]2954-he 's [a good giant]2956-a good giant ! "[601-many little voices] cried [many little voices]601-many little voices . " [He]2954-he 's [a giant]2958-a giant ! "[2690-one] objected [one]2690-one . " [He]2954-he is rather big , "[603-another] assented [another]603-another , " but littleness is n't everything ! It wo n't keep [you]0-i from growing big and stupid except [you]0-i take care ! "[603-another] [I]0-i rose on [my]0-i elbow and stared . Above and about and below [me]0-i stood a multitude of [children , apparently of all ages]604-children , apparently of all ages , [some just able to run alone]605-some just able to run alone , and [some about twelve or thirteen]606-some about twelve or thirteen . [Three or four]607-three or four seemed older . [They]607-three or four stood in a small knot , a little apart , and were less excited than the rest . [The many]608-the many were chattering in groups , declaiming and contradicting , like [a crowd of grown people in [a city]610-a city]609-a crowd of grown people in a city , only with greater merriment , better manners , and more sense . [I]0-i gathered that , by the approach of [my]0-i hand to a second apple , [they]607-three or four knew that [I]0-i liked the first ; but how from that [they]607-three or four argued [me]0-i good , [I]0-i did not see , nor wondered that one of [them]607-three or four at least should suggest caution . [I]0-i did not open [my]0-i mouth , for [I]0-i was afraid of frightening [them]607-three or four , and sure [I]0-i should learn more by listening than by asking questions . For [I]0-i understood nearly all [they]607-three or four said — at which [I]0-i was not surprised : to understand is not more wonderful than to love . There came a movement and slight dispersion among [them]607-three or four , and presently [a sweet , innocent - looking , lovingly roguish little fellow]611-a sweet , innocent - looking , lovingly roguish little fellow handed [me]0-i a huge green apple . Silence fell on [the noisy throng]612-the noisy throng ; all waited expectant . " Eat , [good giant]2959-good giant , "[611-a sweet , innocent - looking , lovingly roguish little fellow] [he]611-a sweet , innocent - looking , lovingly roguish little fellow said . [I]0-i sat up , took the apple , smiled thanks , and would have eaten ; but the moment [I]0-i bit into it , [I]0-i flung it far away . [I]0-i came to the ground at last , overwhelmed with [the lovely little goblins]613-the lovely little goblins . " Good , [good giant]2959-good giant ! "[607-three or four] The babble of [their]607-three or four talk sprang up afresh , and ever the jubilant shout would rise anew from hundreds of clear little throats . Again came a sudden silence . [Those around [me]0-i]614-those around me drew back ; [those atop of [me]0-i]615-those atop of me got off and began trying to set [me]0-i on [my]0-i feet . " Make haste ! much haste ! [He]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow saw [you]2959-good giant throw [his]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow apple away ! "[616-a little girl] Before [she]616-a little girl ended , [I]0-i was on [my]0-i feet . [She]616-a little girl stood pointing up [the slope]617-the slope . On the brow of it was [a clownish , bad - looking fellow]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow , a few inches taller than [myself]0-i . [He]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow looked hostile , but [I]0-i saw no reason to fear [him]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow , for [he]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow had no weapon , and [[my]0-i little friends]619-my little friends had vanished every one . [He]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow began to descend , and [I]0-i , in the hope of better footing and position , to go up . [He]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow growled like a beast as [he]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow turned toward [me]0-i . Reaching a more level spot , [I]0-i stood and waited for [him]618-a clownish , bad - looking fellow .
